{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"loginStatus":"reg","estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T07:14:40Z","duplicateGroupId":"29354887988","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"ACCOUNTING","domains":["IND"],"score":"90"},{"name":"BUSINESS OPERATIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"72"},{"name":"MANAGERS & SUPERVISORS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"67"},{"name":"FREELANCE EMPLOYMENT","domains":["SUB"],"score":"64"},{"name":"TAX LAW","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"SOCIAL SECURITY","domains":["SUB"],"score":"79"},{"name":"SMALL BUSINESS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"TAXES & TAXATION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"91"},{"name":"MARKETING & ADVERTISING","domains":["IND"],"score":"54"},{"name":"SELF EMPLOYMENT","domains":["SUB"],"score":"79"},{"name":"US SOCIAL SECURITY","domains":["SUB"],"score":"79"},{"name":"BUDGETS","domains":["IND"],"score":"79"},{"name":"INTERIOR DECORATING","domains":["SUB"],"score":"60"},{"name":"MARKETING & ADVERTISING AGENCIES","domains":["IND"],"score":"67"},{"name":"THANKSGIVING","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"BUSINESS SOFTWARE","domains":["IND"],"score":"67"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; NEW YORK, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"93"}],"wordCount":"871","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395769157&p=2kx&v=1&x=5M_n39BHeWYYHVsyQH_82Q","id":"29395769157","content":"NEW YORK \u2014 With the start of tax season, stress levels are rising at many small businesses. \n \nEven owners who are organized, keep good books and stay in touch with their accountants can find compiling returns to be a painful process. One reason is that tax laws change often, said Rosamaria Bravo, a certified public accountant with the firm MBAF in Miami. \n \nOne of this year\u2019s big differences: Partnership returns must be filed by March 15, a month earlier than in the past. And companies known as C corporations have a filing deadline of mid-April, after having a March due date in past years. \n \n\u201cIt\u2019s very hard to stay on top of all the information,\u201d Bravo said. \u201cThe average business owner is more worried about their day-to-day operations.\u201d \n \nHere\u2019s a look at some lessons small business owners learned: \n Use software wisely  \nWhen Christina Divigard started an advertising agency, she bought accounting software and began keeping the company\u2019s books herself. When tax season arrived, she discovered that out of inexperience, she\u2019d incorrectly entered some information and misclassified some types of deductions. It took two weeks to get her books in order. \n \n\u201cIf I had to do it all over again, I would have put more effort and budget behind setting up systems properly from the get-go,\u201d said Divigard, managing director of New York-based Valvespring. \n \nDivigard subsequently hired a bookkeeper to help set up accounts and understand how to input income and expenses. She also learned more about the need to put expenses into different accounting categories \u2014 for example, meals during a business trip are different from meals to entertain customers under the tax law. \n \nHaving a system that is correctly set up has reduced the chance of errors, and even if Divigard has to do repair work, \u201cnow it takes me a day rather than two weeks.\u201d \n Keep up with the changes  \nComplying with tax law revisions can be hard even with a bookkeeper and accountant, Barbara Karpf has learned. As of this year, businesses must file W-2 forms and 1099 forms with the IRS by Jan. 31. \n \nWhile companies were previously required to give those forms to workers by the end of January, they didn\u2019t have to get them to the government until the end of February. The government can charge a penalty if it gets the forms late. \n \nThat created extra pressure for Karpf. Her home decor company, DecoratorsBest, moved offices in New York right after Black Friday and Cyber Monday, two of its busiest sales days. After she hired movers and a painter for the new space, she realized she needed to get information like Social Security numbers and addresses from eight people. \n \nWell into January she was still getting all the information together so 1099 forms for freelancers and other contract workers could get to the government, as well as the workers, on time. \n \n\u201cIt\u2019s more work in a shorter period of time,\u201d Karpf said. \n Keep track of expenses  \nWhen an owner is running a business day by day and also trying to do long-term strategic planning, details like tax-deductible expenses can get lost in the shuffle, creating a headache later. \n \nDeborah Sweeney has learned to look at her books monthly to be sure expenses like charitable donations and the costs of employee meetings are entered properly. \n \n\u201cThat way, we don\u2019t have to scramble at the end of the year,\u201d said Sweeney, owner of MyCorporation.com, a Calabasas, California-based company that helps businesses incorporate online. \n \nSweeney recalls errors of past years, such as not taking a deduction for a service contract on a printer. She has also learned to take her questions to her accountant to be sure she\u2019s not missing some of the finer points of rules about deductions. \n \nFor example: \u201cHow do we categorize new furniture \u2014 do we write it off or depreciate it? What amount of an owner\u2019s health care costs is deductible?\u201d \n Find the best help  \nDiane Hamilton, though, has struggled to find an accountant who\u2019s a good fit for her company, which makes computer and phone apps. \n \nShe has worked with large accounting firms in the Richmond, Virginia, area where her Binary Formations business is located. But the bills climbed as she called with questions. \n \n\u201cYou look at how much they charge and the amount of revenue you bring in, and it isn\u2019t working,\u201d she said. \n \nWhen Hamilton switched to a much smaller accounting firm, she found herself doing as much work as when she tried to handle her taxes herself. \n \nShe\u2019s still hoping to find the right tax professional for her company. \n \nTry to hold costs down \n \nBrad Chandler estimates it costs his real estate company $70,000 a year to compile returns for the federal government and for Maryland, Virginia, and Washington, D.C. That\u2019s a five-fold increase in five years. \n \n\u201cA lot of it is the sheer complexity of the laws, which are changing so much,\u201d said Chandler, CEO of Springfield, Virginia-based Express Homebuyers. \n \nFor example, Chandler said, depreciation laws are shifting annually, and the health care law brought more paperwork. \n \nOccasionally, the company gets additional tax bills, which raise a question for Chandler and his chief financial officer. \n \n\u201cDo we send it to our CPA [to handle] for $200 or $300 an hour, or just pay the bill?\u201d he said.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"Joyce M. UNITED STATES; CALIFORNIA, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"}],"wordCount":"934","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395769156&p=2kx&v=1&x=WXouV86YSR17kgr2_9JnOg","id":"29395769156","content":"NEW YORK \u2014 The tech industry brought us self-driving cars, artificial intelligence and 3-D printers. But when it comes to racial and gender diversity, its leading companies are no trailblazers. \n \nDespite loudly touted efforts to hire more blacks, Latinos and women, especially in technical and leadership positions, diversity numbers at the largest tech companies are barely budging. \n \nIn 2014, 2 percent of Googlers were black and 3 percent were Hispanic, numbers that have not changed since. The picture is similar at Facebook and Twitter. Microsoft is slightly more racially diverse (though not when it comes to gender) and Apple even more so, though still not reflective of the U.S. population. Amazon is more racially diverse still, although it counts a large, lower-wage warehouse workforce in its totals. \n \nWomen, meanwhile, make up less than a third of the workforce at many companies \u2014 even less in engineering and other technical jobs. \n \nTech companies themselves tend to blame a \u201cpipeline problem,\u201d meaning a shortage of women and minorities with technical qualifications. But a number of academic experts, industry employees and diversity advocates say there\u2019s a bigger problem. Silicon Valley, they argue, has failed to challenge its own unstated assumptions about what makes for great tech employees. \n \n\u201cThe people who are doing the hiring are not changing their thinking around what they view as qualified,\u201d says Leslie Miley, engineering director at the message-service startup Slack. \n \nHiring managers, he says, spend too much time worrying that applicants who don\u2019t fit techie stereotypes aren\u2019t \u201cGoogle-y enough or Facebook-y enough or Apple-y enough or Twitter-y enough.\u201d \n \nMiley, who is African-American, previously worked as an engineer at Twitter, Apple, Google and Yahoo. \n Industry trying  \nCompanies are spending a lot of time and money on improving diversity. Two years ago, Intel splashily set itself the goal of achieving full representation in its workforce by 2020. Despite committing $300 million to the effort and making some early progress, Intel acknowledges there is \u201ca great deal of work to be done.\u201d \n \nSimilar programs are in place throughout the industry, from outreach at high schools and historically black colleges to internship and mentoring programs and sponsorships for coding boot camps. So far, to little avail. \n \nWhy? Interviews with more than 30 tech workers, executives and diversity advocates suggest the blame lies with subtle biases in hiring, unwelcoming work environments and a paucity of diverse role models in top positions. \n \nAniyia Williams, founder and CEO of the startup Tinsel, says companies should focus on their own culture rather than blaming external factors they can\u2019t control, such as limited computer-science education in U.S. schools. It\u2019s not enough to release diversity reports and say, \u201cOh, not a lot has changed, but it\u2019s the world, not us that\u2019s the problem,\u201d she says. \n \nWilliams, who is African-American, says she has made sure to hire women as well as underrepresented minorities. Tinsel makes tech jewelry targeted at women. \n Why it matters  \nDiversity isn\u2019t just about fairness. It\u2019s about having designers who reflect the diversity of the people they are designing for. For tech companies hoping to reach millions or billions of users, a lack of diversity could mean their products \u201cwill not appeal to a large population,\u201d says Lillian Cassel, chairwoman of computer sciences at Villanova University. \n \nDiverse perspectives can also help prevent grievous errors \u2014 such as a problem that arose at Google in 2015, when a photo-recognition feature misidentified black faces as gorillas. \n \nSome related missteps: \n \nSnapchat released two photo filters that contorted facial features into bucktoothed Asian caricatures or blackface. One was later withdrawn after public outcry. The other \u201cexpired,\u201d and the company said it won\u2019t put it back into circulation. \n \nAirbnb initially took no steps to prevent hosts from discriminating against guests whose profile photos showed they were black. The practice was corrected after an outcry. \n \nTwitter took nearly a decade to tackle the harassment of women and minorities on its service. \n \nIn a New York Times opinion piece, Microsoft researcher Kate Crawford urged companies working on artificial intelligence to address diversity, warning that otherwise \u201cwe will see ingrained forms of bias built into the artificial intelligence of the future.\u201d \n Into the pipeline  \nSome 11 percent of computer science graduates were black and 9 percent were Hispanic in the 2013-14 school year, according to the latest data from the U.S. Department of Education. Yet only 4 percent of Google\u2019s 2015 hires were black, and 3 percent were Hispanic. At Intel, fewer than 5 percent of hires were black and 8 percent were Hispanic. Numbers at other tech companies are comparable. \n \nMajor tech companies have a long tradition of hiring applicants from top-tier universities \u2014 and those universities also have a problem with diversity, even if they\u2019re doing slightly better than the companies. Some minority applicants, meanwhile, earn their computer-science chops through community colleges or coding boot camps instead \u2014 places often overlooked by recruiters. \n \nThe few minorities hired into big tech companies can often feel alienated in overwhelmingly white (and sometimes Asian) environments. \n When the culture doesn\u2019t fit  \nSilicon Valley startups like to talk about \u201cculture fit\u201d \u2014 in theory, the question of whether a job candidate\u2019s attitude and behavior meshes well with a company. In practice, though, it can mean that since a lot of people are white and male, they \u201chire what they know,\u201d says Dave McClure, a prominent angel investor in Silicon Valley. \n \nLarger companies such as Facebook publicly eschew discussions of \u201cfit,\u201d although the notion can unwittingly seep into hiring practices. For example, a 2013 study found that words used in engineering and programming job listings could serve to discourage women from applying. Words like \u201ccompetitive,\u201d \u2018\u2018dominant\u201d and \u201cleader,\u201d can make a job seem less appealing to women in a field that is already male-dominated.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"Barbara Ortutay"},"topics":[{"name":"Internet latest","group":"Internet"},{"name":"Business latest","group":"Business"}],"title":"Little progress in tech diversity","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Denton","zipCode":"76201","state":"Texas","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Denton","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Denton Record-Chronicle","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169660450","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"115"},"name":"Denton Record-Chronicle","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Business","Professional","Local","Geographic"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.dentonrc.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":["https://www.google.com/diversity/","http://newsroom.fb.com/news/2016/07/facebook-diversity-update-positive-hiring-trends-show-progress/","https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/diversity/inside-microsoft/default.aspx","http://www.apple.com/diversity/","https://www.amazon.com/b?node=10080092011","https://bigstory.ap.org/0e806720877242cfb96d187511c09eb3","http://bigstory.ap.org/ad72803420e84e51a09ceff025e6ea35","http://www.fortefoundation.org/site/DocServer/gendered_wording_JPSP.pdf?docID=16121"],"sequenceId":"695194344405","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:14:40Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"92"}],"wordCount":"491","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395769180&p=2kx&v=1&x=xzk1QMB3ycLaHBqxlnV0Bw","id":"29395769180","content":"5:38 p.m. MT Jan. 28, 2017 \n    \nSteve Fischer \n  \nAt age 18, I attended a party where police found tiny amounts of marijuana. Without funds for an attorney, I accepted deferred probation. It has followed me my entire life. \n \nI graduated from college, law, and graduate school, yet I had to endure a hearing to ascertain my fitness to practice. It also caused employment rejection. \n \nLater, as assistant county attorney in El Paso, and elected district attorney in Willacy County, I routinely dismissed pot cases. Prosecutor\u2019s offices have limited budgets, yet mountains of cases. Dismissing marijuana offenses, allowed me to send more dangerous criminals to prison. \n \nEven probation for pot was wasteful. Curfews and reporting requirements should be for prowlers and burglars, not pot smokers. \n \nThis problem persists, as 620,000 Americans were arrested for pot last year. Yes, illegal marijuana creates jobs for probation officers, prosecutors, bailiffs, chemists, clerical staff and many more; however taxpayers get soaked. \n \nCalifornia and three other states legalized marijuana on Nov. 8. Voters were persuaded by the Colorado experience, where $2.4 billion in revenues and 17,000 jobs were created in legalization\u2019s first year. Some of this boom comes from visiting Texans. \n \nThe Denver Post polled, \u201cWould you repeal legalization?\u201d The answer; \u201cNo\u201d, by a 51 percent to 36 percent margin. Gallup\u2019s 2016 poll showed support for legalization has grown to 60 percent nationally, and recent studies demonstrate no increased use among youngsters since legalization. Colorado is booming, and other states want what they\u2019re smoking. \n \nThe old \u201cReefer Madness\u201d arguments against marijuana have been dispelled. Today\u2019s legalization opponents such as Insys Therapeutics, which develops synthetic painkillers, poured $500,000 into the \u201cNo\u201d vote in Arizona. It\u2019s these legal painkillers which cause so much addiction and harm. \n \nPrescription drugs increase our health costs and Big Pharma doesn\u2019t want competition. The Catholic Church was also a huge contributor, with the Boston Archdiocese donating $850,000 to oppose Massachusetts\u2019 marijuana initiative. \n \nOne lingering anti-pot argument is that people will ingest and drive. This happens anyway and it will be illegal everywhere. \n \nNot satisfied, opponents wonder how they will test for marijuana. Field tests still work, but how about we just arm each officer with a chocolate bar, and they could cuff the stoned drivers as they grab for it. \n \nLegalization will come eventually, as it\u2019s only the oldest age groups who are opposed. \n \nAn estimated 15 million Americans use marijuana regularly, and about half our population has admitted trying marijuana. \n \nMarijuana decriminalization bills for the 2017 Texas Legislature, have been filed, including one by El Paso\u2019s own Joe Moody. \n \nRepublicans are increasingly in favor, because of the fiscal benefits and individual freedom arguments. Democrats are already there, and almost everyone wants to decrease the power of the violent drug cartels who smuggle pot across our border. \n \nLet\u2019s legalize it, and have Mexico put up the wall to keep Texans from trafficking marijuana into their country. \n \nEl Paso attorney Steve Fischer has been a professor of criminology and a Texas State Bar director. Sfischerlaw@gmail.com. \n \nRead or Share this story: http://www.elpasotimes.com/story/opinion/columnists/2017/01/28/fischer-past-time-legalize-marijuana/97196558/","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"Steve Fischer, Guest columnist"},"topics":[{"name":"US news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Opinion latest","group":"Society"},{"name":"Illegal drugs news","group":"Society"}],"title":"ColumnistsFischer: Time to legalize marijuanaFischer: Time to legalize marijuanaCalifornia and three other states legalized marijuana in November.Columnists6hours, 36minutes ago","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"El Paso","zipCode":"79999","state":"Texas","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"El Paso","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"El Paso Times","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169667696","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"1721"},"name":"El Paso Times","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Geographic","Local","Standard","News"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.elpasotimes.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695194345086","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:14:40Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

Let us be honest. As the governor of Edo State, we have had to sponsor, and the records are there, first, Nigerian medical doctors, who request for it in black and white that they had to be treated in India, the UK or US and they give me a variety of reasons why they need that foreign medical check. \n \n\u201c\u200eI have seen villagers approaching me that they had prostrate (cancer). They had gone to some local hospitals and they had challenges and they want support to go to India. I had used state funds to support very ordinary people and all kinds of people, including the media, politicians and farmers. \n \n\u201c\u200eI have had course to travel outside Nigeria for a comprehensive medical check, when I was in doubt. It is not tied to salaries but the sustainable funding of the university. \n \n\u201cThe two states are supposed to give LAUTECH N295m as subventions every month but they have not been doing this. \n \n\u201cOyo State owes us N2.3bn and Osun State is owing N5.3bn but the two states just paid N500m. This is not enough. Although we are also considering the economic realities on ground, that is why we want them to state categorically state how they intend to pay the balance of N7.1bn. \n \n\u201cIs it going to be monthly or how? They have to state this and assure us that from January 2017, they will no longer owe. {"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T07:14:43Z","duplicateGroupId":"29395404563","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"DESTINATIONS & ATTRACTIONS","domains":["IND"],"score":"76"},{"name":"WORLD WAR I","domains":["SUB"],"score":"63"},{"name":"DOG RACING","domains":["SUB"],"score":"73"},{"name":"AWARDS & PRIZES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"68"},{"name":"WORLD WAR II","domains":["SUB"],"score":"60"},{"name":"DOGS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"91"},{"name":"AUSTRALIA; NEW SOUTH WALES, AUSTRALIA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"90"},{"name":"MELBOURNE, AUSTRALIA; AUSTRALIA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"71"},{"name":"AUSTRALIA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"AUSTRALIA; AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY","domains":["GEO"],"score":"70"},{"name":"SYDNEY, AUSTRALIA; AUSTRALIA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"71"}],"wordCount":"410","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395769430&p=2kx&v=1&x=L3qNya8mHtx2S2YCBPCUKw","id":"29395769430","content":"An impressive 154 dachsunds turned out for this year's dachshund races at the Bungendore Show on Sunday. Organisers claim this a record number of the little dogs in the one place at the one time. exit   \nMark Ellis, the organiser of Sunday's Werriwa Wiener Dash at the Bungendore Show, believes the turnout of 154 dachshunds for the event constitutes a world record for the number of the sausage dogs in one place at one time. \n \n\"We had miniatures, long hairs, short hairs, standards and wire hairs,\" he said. \"They came from all over; some even travelled from Melbourne. \n \nWhile Mr Ellis wasn't able to engage the attention of the people from Guinness, who ruled the record being sought was too \"specialised\" to interest them, he is happy to claim the record with any other contenders needing to prove him wrong. \n \nAlthough the quirky event, which has captured the imagination of dachshund lovers from across NSW and the ACT, is only in its second year it has already become one of the feature events of the Bungendore Show. \n \nThis year's dash winner was Buddy, owned by Jacqueline Winzenberg of Page in the ACT. Buddy's award was presented by NSW Deputy Premier and local member John Barilaro. \n \nOne hundred and twenty seven dogs turned up for the inaugural event in 2016. \n \nBungendore Show, which was first held in the 1840s, has gone from strength to strength in recent decades, this year's showgirl, Hanna Darmody, 22, said. \n \nMs Darmody, whose family own a Bungendore butchery, said she could recall helping with the catering at the show as a toddler almost 20 years ago. \n \n\"I've seen the event grow as the town has grown,\" she said. \"It is a great bridge between country and city; the showgirl competition is a good way to get young people involved and promotes opportunities in agriculture.\" \n \nShow organisers said this year's event, which enjoyed the best weather conditions in three years, was an unqualified success with more than 2000 people passing through the gates before lunch. \n \nIn addition to the usual attractions in the show ring and the pavilions and the dachshund dash, the 2017 event offered visitors a chance to get a close look at the Anzac Centennial 18 pounder gun. \n \nThe World War I-era weapon, which also saw service during World War II,was restored by the Royal Australian Artillery Company in conjunction with veteran coach builder Jim Frecklington. \n \nThe story Werriwa Wiener dash claims world dachsund record first appeared on The Sydney Morning Herald .","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Australia news","group":"Regional"}],"title":"Werriwa Wiener dash claims world dachsund record","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Oceania","subregion":"Australia and New Zealand","zipCode":"2153","state":"New South Wales","countryCode":"AU","zipArea":"Bella Vista","country":"Australia"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Hills News","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169714159","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"2"},"name":"Hills News","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Geographic","Local"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.hillsnews.com.au","publisher":"Fairfax Media"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695194347691","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:14:43Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

NEW SOUTH WALES, AUSTRALIA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"95"}],"wordCount":"492","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395769465&p=2kx&v=1&x=JxFR436V6L8PpY_szj51IA","id":"29395769465","content":"Labor warns that the NSW police commissioner must report to two ministers under the change exit   \nThe appointment of a new minister for counter-terrorism in NSW has been slammed by the Labor opposition as irresponsible and against the public interest. \n \nUnveiling acabinet reshuffle on Sunday, Premier Gladys Berejiklian announced corrections minister David Elliott \u2013 not police minister Troy Grant \u2013 would take on the new role. \n \nShe said it was required \"unfortunately due to the circumstances our world is in\". \n \n\"The sad reality is that this is an area of focus for governments around the world \u2013 NSW is already working closely with the Commonwealth and I want the Minister to take this work forward,\" Ms Berejiklian said. \n \n\"Mr Elliott will work closely with the Attorney General, Minister for Police, the Minister for Education, the Minister for Family and Community Services and the Minister for Multiculturalism, as well as our federal counterparts, to ensure a whole-of-government approach to this issue\". \n \nUnder the change, the Terrorism (Commonwealth Powers) Actand the Terrorism (Police Powers) Act will remain the responsibility of the Attorney General. \n \nMr Elliott will provide strategic policy direction for counter-terrorism in NSW, while the police will manage the tactical and operational response toterrorist attacks or threats. \n \nMr Elliott told Fairfax Media: \"Over the coming weeks I will be working to coordinate all stakeholders to ensure that the people of NSW can sleep soundly in the knowledge that we are as best prepared for any contingency as we can be.\" \n \nBut opposition leader Luke Foley said the appointment was the result of an irresponsible deal. He alleged that the Liberals wanted to wrest police from Mr Grant, a senior Nationals MP. \n \n\"The Nationals wanted police, the right wing faction of the Liberals wanted police,\" he said. \"So she split it in two.\" \n \n\"It's the police who keep us safe from terrorism,\" Mr Foley said. \n \n\"The police commissioner now has to report to two people. It's scandalous and another deal that is counter to the public interest.\" \n \nMeanwhile, the troubled relationship between the NSW attorney-general and minister for police has been addressed, with Ms Berejiklian confirming a reshaping of the much maligned \"justice cluster\". \n \nThe arrangement, whereby as justice and police minister MrGrant held a more senior position than then attorney-general Gabrielle Upton, was heavily criticised by the legal profession. \n \nThe NSW Bar Association said it provided Mr Grant \"with unprecedented power in determining legal policy without the historical checks and balances\". \n \nThe NSW Law Society warned the arrangement meantpolice were \"ostensibly responsible for criminal law policy, while at the same time, the traditional roles of the attorney-general as first law officer of the state, which includes preserving civil liberties, are being eroded\". \n \nMs Berejiklian has confirmed the cluster has been reworked so that new attorney-general Mark Speakman, SC, is the lead minister. \n \nThe story New counter terrorism role slammed as 'against the public interest' first appeared on The Sydney Morning Herald the proposal, Yes California Independence Campaign, was cleared to begin attempting to collect nearly 600,000 voter signatures needed to place the plan on the ballot. \n \n\u201cIn our view, the that states the U.S. Constitution is the supreme law. \n \nIf approved, it calls for scheduling a vote in 2019 to ask voters, \u201cShould California become a free, sovereign and independent country?\u201d \n \n\u201cAmerica already hates California, and America votes on emotions,\u201d Marcus Evans, vice president of Yes California told the Los Angeles Times. \u201cI think we\u2019d have We\u2019re starting in downtown Denton at the PointBank Black Box Theatre on Hickory Street, and we\u2019ll head west toward the Square. \n \nBefore we take our first step, though, let\u2019s look down at the sidewalk. Notice the pattern? On both sides of Hickory Street between Bell and Locust streets, a brick band runs parallel to the concrete. Evenly placed within this band, granite squares are laid into the concrete. \n \nWe are on the Denton Arts Walk of Fame. \n \nThis stone here in front of the Black Box Theatre celebrates musician Louise Tobin. Her\u2019s was the first marker unveiled back in 2015, the Walk of Fame\u2019s inaugural year. Twelve granite squares were engraved between 2015 and 2016 honoring artists with Denton connections. Texas Poet Laureate Karla Morton\u2019s was next after Tobin\u2019s. \n \nEvery one of the honored-in-granite are artists of myriad genres ranging from music, literature and theater to film, architecture, visual arts and more. Brave Combo, Pops Carter, Midlake, O\u2019Neil Ford and Jesus Morales are examples of other recipients. \n \nAs we make our way along the Arts Walk of Fame, you\u2019ll notice many more granite stones than the 12 engraved thus far. That\u2019s because the Walk of Fame funding happens in waves, by fiscal years. Someday, every granite stone will be engraved. A multitude of talent connects to Denton, but there\u2019s only money enough to tackle such a vast project a step at a time, so to speak. \n \nThis past Thursday, the Denton Main Street Association announced the 2017 Arts Walk of Fame inductees. There are eight on this year\u2019s list. In case you haven\u2019t seen the lineup yet, here it is: \n \nLeon Breedon, musician \n \nJohn Ford Coley, musician \n \nPaula Blincoe Collins, sculptor \n \nCarlotta Corpron, photographer \n \nMargo Jones, producer/director \n \nTom \u201cBones\u201d Malone, musician \n \nLou Marini, musician \n \nNeal Slater, musician \n \nThe Arts Walk of Fame is a facet of the Downtown Master Plan, a plan that resulted from a citizen-driven idea developed in 1995 called \u201cVision for Denton \u2014 the 21st Century.\u201d That idea included an arts and entertainment corridor along East Hickory as a major priority. \n \nToday, we Dentonites and thousands of visitors to our city enjoy the fruits of that focus every day. Downtown is the thriving, culturally rich city center, and still growing. \n \n\u201cThere are more than 100 names on a list compiled by the Arts Walk of Fame Committee,\u201d said Julie Glover, downtown development manager and city staff liaison for the project. \u201cWe envision anywhere from eight to 12 inductees each year long into the future. Public input will continue to be valuable in their considerations.\u201d \n \nHow does the committee assess potential inductees? Nominees must have been born in Denton, or attended school or spent their formative/creative years here or had a national impact on our cultural heritage. \n \nOther considerations include longevity of career, professional achievements, contributions to the Denton arts community or contribution to national arts. \n \nThe more honorees are engraved in granite, the more value I believe the Arts Walk of Fame will be to our Denton tourism product. It memorializes talented individuals who have contributed to the local arts community and expresses appreciation to them. \n \nGranite stones include the name of the artist and their claim to fame, such as musician, sculptor, actor, journalist. For those who want to delve deeper, understand artists\u2019 bodies of work and their Denton connection, those details are available at www.discoverdenton.com. \n \nIn the business of delivering the best possible #dentoning experiences, we all see a day in the not-too-distant future when people will linger at each granite marker and employ augmented reality on their smartphones to get the full stories. \n \nOne 2017 Arts Walk of Fame event is already on the books. John Ford Coley, American singer and musician best known for the 1970s hit duo England Dan & John Ford Coley, will participate in person when his marker is unveiled on Saturday, June 10. \n \n\u201cI\u2019m highly honored that I am included in the Denton Arts Walk of Fame,\u201d Coley said. \n \nEveryone is invited to all of these events, and when possible, artists are there, too. Louise Tobin was. Karla Morton was. John Ford Coley will be. Many more in the days and years to come will be, too. \n \nOur walk today was Hickory Street to Locust Street and then back again on the other side of the road. This year, we\u2019ll add eight more names among these granite markers for a total of 20. Imagine the wealth of this walk in just a few more years. It\u2019s happening, one step at a time. \n \nKIM PHILLIPS is vice president of the Denton Convention & Visitors Bureau at the Denton Chamber of Commerce. {"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T07:14:46Z","duplicateGroupId":"29395769624","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"POLITICAL ORGANIZATIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"73"},{"name":"ELECTIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"LEGISLATIVE BODIES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"POLITICAL PARTIES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"US PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATES 2016","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"RELIGION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"FREEDOM OF RELIGION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"86"},{"name":"US DEMOCRATIC PARTY","domains":["SUB"],"score":"77"},{"name":"LIBERALISM","domains":["SUB"],"score":"86"},{"name":"EDUCATION SYSTEMS & INSTITUTIONS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"UNITED STATES","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; WEST VIRGINIA, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"HILLARY RODHAM CLINTON","domains":["PEO"],"score":"79"}],"wordCount":"384","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395769624&p=2kx&v=1&x=J-A_4cVvmfh1oYQMrDNeMA","id":"29395769624","content":"I have some thoughts on the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact. \n \nIn the 2016 election, roughly 70 percent of West Virginians voted for Trump. Had the NPVIC been in effect, W.Va. electors would have been required to cast their votes for Hillary Clinton because she won the nationwide popular vote. The same would be true in all the states Trump carried. The NPVIC would have made electors puppets of Clinton and the Democratic Party. \n \nThankfully, the NPVIC was not in effect in 2016. \n \nWe elect our members of congress and senators to represent us in Washington. We should choose our electors to do the same in the Electoral College. If electors aren\u2019t free to represent their constituents, why have electors? Why have an Electoral College? \n \nThe Electoral College concept reflects our founding fathers\u2019 concerns with separation of powers and checks and balances to prevent a future tyranny in our country. That is the reason they gave the individual states so much power and latitude in the selection of their electors and the rules concerning how electors vote. \n \nThe NPVIC negates those separations of powers and checks and balances by shifting the power to decide elections into the blue state population centers and leaving rural red states out of the process. \n \nAllowing too much power in the hand of any one individual, political group or area of the country is a form of tyranny. \n \nThe , period. \n \nIn his Jan. 15 letter, Ralph Chambers correctly states \u201cCongress shall make no law respecting the establishment of a religion or prohibiting the free exercise thereof\u201d appears in the First Amendment. \n \nMr. Chambers graciously makes my case for me. No where is the term \u201cseparation of church and state\u201d mentioned in the Constitution. \n \nThe term \u201cseparation of church and state\u201d was coined in the 1960s when liberal judges began their attacks on our religious freedoms by banning prayer and Bible reading in public schools. Those decisions should be made by parents, local schools and local officials, not the federal government. \n \nSince then, nativity scenes have been banned from public squares, praying before football games, even saying \u201cMerry Christmas\u201d is forbidden for fear of offending some atheist. \n \nNow one atheist can restrict the free exercise of religion by the majority. \n \nWhat part of \u201cprohibiting the free exercise thereof\u201d can\u2019t liberals understand? \n \nSteve Wolverton \n \nParkersburg","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Society news","group":"Society"},{"name":"Opinion latest","group":"Society"}],"title":"NPVIC is a bad idea","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Wood","zipCode":"26101","state":"West Virginia","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Parkersburg","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"News and Sentinel","feed":{"genre":"Opinion","tags":[],"id":"169707085","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"287"},"name":"News and Sentinel","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Standard","Society"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.newsandsentinel.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695194359570","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:14:46Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

He engaged the after burners and the powerful jet engine responded. Not too many men, past or present, commanded as much power as he simply by pushing a throttle. \n  \nIt was a test flight with no stringent maneuvers or flight formations. Check out the maintenance chart, then free flying until fuel ran low. As a young cadet, he used to envy the senior officers that enjoyed this freedom. Now he knew what he had been missing. He started a barrel roll to full throttle, smiling at his unlimited freedom. Next stop \u2013 the universe! The words of a poem, \u201cand he reached out and touched the face of God\u201d , danced through his mind. \n \nThe fuel indicator warning sounded. Flashing, the red caution light dominated the complex panel of switches and knobs. As a young flight trainee he remembered how he tensed up the first time he was confronted with this situation. Now it was routine. Using professionalism and years of experience, he banked to starboard with only a glance at the panel. He knew where he was and how far he had to go. Part of his discipline and training required him to know his surroundings at all times. \n \nThe landing strip in sight, he felt a slight surge of excitement as he lowered his flaps and dropped his landing gear. Trump's order temporarily bars citizens of seven majority-Muslim countries from entering the United States even if they hold valid visas or permanent residence permits, a move that caught many companies off-guard.\n\nNetflix Inc Chief Executive Reed Hastings called it \"a sad week\" and added: \"It is time to link arms together to protect American values of freedom and opportunity.\"\n\nApple Inc CEO Tim Cook sent a letter to employees saying Trump's order was \"not a policy we support\" and promised to help affected employees.\n\n\"We have reached out to the White House to explain the negative effect on our coworkers and our company,\" Cook added.\n\nElon Musk, the South African-born founder of Tesla and SpaceX who met recently with Trump, said on Twitter: \"The blanket entry ban on citizens from certain primarily Muslim countries is not the best way to address the country\u2019s challenges.\"\n\nAirbnb co-founder and CEO Brian Chesky said: \"Not allowing countries or refugees into America is not right and we must stand with those who are affected.\"\n\nAirbnb will provide free housing to anyone not allowed into the United States, Chesky said.\n\nAaron Levie, the outspoken founder and CEO of online storage company Box Inc, said: \"The executive order on immigration is immoral and antithetical to our values.\"\n\nStranded\n\nFriday's order could be a major headache for tech companies, potentially leaving employees stranded overseas and unable to return to the United States.\n\nAlphabet Inc's Google urgently called back employees from overseas and told ones who might be affected by the ban not to leave the United States.\n\nCEO Sundar Pichai said in an email to staff that more than 100 Google employees were affected by the order, according to a Google executive.\n\nOne Google employee of Iranian nationality with legal US residency made it back to the United States just hours before the order took effect, the executive said.\n\n\"We're concerned about the impact of this order and any proposals that could impose restrictions on Googlers and their families, or that could create barriers to bringing great talent to the US,\" Google said in a statement.\n\nMicrosoft Corp President and Chief Legal Officer Brad Smith said in a company-wide email posted on LinkedIn that 76 company employees were citizens of the seven countries in question and held US work visas, and thus were directly affected by the order.\n\nHe said the company had not determined how many people with green cards, or permanent residence status, might be affected.\n\n\"As a company, Microsoft believes in a strong and balanced high-skilled immigration system,\" Smith said in the post. \"We believe in the importance of protecting legitimate and law-abiding refugees whose very lives may be at stake in immigration proceedings.\"\n\nUber Technologies Inc CEO Travis Kalanick, who has faced criticism from some employees for participating in President Trump's business advisory council, said in a statement that the company would compensate drivers from the seven countries who might not be able to return to the United States for three months or more. He said the company knew of about a dozen affected employees.\n\n\"This ban will impact many innocent people - an issue that I will raise this coming Friday when I go to Washington for President Trump\u2019s first business advisory group meeting,\" Kalanick said.\n\nFacebook Inc CEO Mark Zuckerberg said in a post on Friday that was \"concerned\" about the order and voiced support for immigrants.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Tech latest","group":"Technology"},{"name":"Internet latest","group":"Internet"}],"title":"Tech leaders bash Trump ban","source":{"category":"National","location":{"region":"Asia","subregion":"Southern Asia","countryCode":"BD","country":"Bangladesh"},"editorialRank":"3","name":"Bdnews24.com","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169667953","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"128"},"name":"Bdnews24.com","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["InformationTechnology","Professional"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.bdnews24.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":["https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://bdnews24.com/technology/2017/01/29/us-tech-leaders-sound-alarm-over-trump-immigration-order&src=sdkpreparse","http://www.printfriendly.com/","http://delivery.ritsads.com/w/1.0/rc?cs=ff614e8f84&cb=INSERT_RANDOM_NUMBER_HERE","http://disqus.com/?ref_noscript","http://disqus.com/","http://delivery.ritsads.com/w/1.0/rc?cs=9e5f0d291c&cb=INSERT_RANDOM_NUMBER_HERE"],"sequenceId":"695194360944","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:14:46Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[{"url":"http://d30fl32nd2baj9.cloudfront.net/media/2017/01/29/sundar-pichai.jpg/ALTERNATES/w640/Sundar-Pichai.jpg"}],"video":[]}}

{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T07:14:46Z","duplicateGroupId":"29385752900","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"BIRDS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"MAMMALS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"BIRDING","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"WILDERNESS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"69"},{"name":"STATE PARKS","domains":["IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"DISABLED ACCESS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"50"},{"name":"WILDLIFE","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"TRAVEL, HOSPITALITY & TOURISM","domains":["IND"],"score":"77"},{"name":"PRESS RELEASES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"WILDLIFE CONSERVATION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"74"},{"name":"ZOOS & AQUARIUMS","domains":["IND"],"score":"89"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; NEW MEXICO, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"WHEELING, WV, USA; UNITED STATES; WEST VIRGINIA, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"54"},{"name":"AMARILLO, TX, USA; UNITED STATES; TEXAS, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"70"},{"name":"ALBUQUERQUE, NM, USA; UNITED STATES; NEW MEXICO, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; OHIO, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"92"},{"name":"COLUMBUS, OH, USA; UNITED STATES; OHIO, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"86"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; TEXAS, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; WEST VIRGINIA, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"93"}],"wordCount":"690","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395769672&p=2kx&v=1&x=_Qs6C9BO8zM7oU2_XDBVUA","id":"29395769672","content":"As the longer days of spring and the warmer travel season approach, I\u2019m reminded that I always hope for the best. Perhaps I\u2019ll see something I\u2019ve never seen before or do something I\u2019ve never done before. My motto is, \u201cWhere there\u2019s hope, there\u2019s adventure.\u201d \n \nTwo years ago, for example, my wife and I visited friends in New Mexico. We survived a nighttime lightning storm as our tram descended from Sandia Peak. We hoped we wouldn\u2019t see any rattlesnakes, despite signs at every rest stop reading, \u201cBeware \u2014 Rattlesnakes!\u201d \n \nSometimes it takes years returning to the same place to see a particular species. It took me nine years to find a Swainson\u2019s warbler in West Virginia\u2019s New River Gorge. This year I plan to visit Ohio\u2019s Magee Marsh in mid-May to find a migrating Connecticut warbler. It\u2019s the only eastern warbler I\u2019ve never seen. \n \nAnd then there are hoped for surprises. One year we crossed the Texas panhandle on I-40 when we saw a sign for Palo Duro Canyon State Park near Amarillo. We had never heard of it, so we checked it out. Teeming with prairie dogs and southwestern birds, this little-known gem remains one of our favorite discoveries. \n \nI have yet to decide where to travel this year, but I do plan two return trips to places visited years ago. The West Virginia State Wildlife Center is only about two hours from home, so a late April trip sounds good. The Center is essentially a zoo featuring West Virginia wildlife. The grounds include a picnic area and a fishing pond. \n \nA 1.25-mile wheelchair accessible interpretive trail winds through a mature hardwood forest and connects spacious enclosures. The trail provides excellent photo opportunities for many species on display. \n \nThe center is located in north-central West Virginia about 12 miles south of Buckhannon on State Route 20. For more information, visit wvdnr.gov/wildlife/wildlifecenter.shtm or call 304-924-6211. \n \nThe other location I plan to visit is The Wilds in Ohio, located south of I-70 between Columbus and Wheeling. The Wilds is a 9,000-plus acre safari park and conservation center located on reclaimed strip mines. \n \nThe best way to enjoy the Wilds is on an open-air tram tour. You will get great looks at larger species in their expansive enclosures, and periodic stops give close up looks at the smaller species. \n \nYou\u2019ll see familiar species such as ostrich, rhinos, giraffes, zebras, and cheetahs and new or less familiar species such as African painted dogs, Przewalski\u2019s wild horses, Persian onagers, and Sichuan takins. And the open expanses that comprise the Wilds provide excellent birding for native grassland species. For more information, visit thewilds.org or call 740-638-5030. \n \nWhile we\u2019re in the neighborhood, a side trip to the Columbus Zoo and Aquarium (columbuszoo.org) will be hard to resist. It\u2019s one of the country\u2019s great zoos. The favorite part of my most recent visit was the best bear exhibit I\u2019ve ever seen. \n \nFinally, for a four to six day road trip, I suggest driving 400 miles along U.S. Route 6 across the northern tier of Pennsylvania from Lake Erie to the Delaware River. Among the highlights along the way are the Allegheny National Forest (fs.usda.gov/allegheny), the Lumber Museum in Coudersport (lumbermuseum.org), and the Pennsylvania Grand Canyon (pacanyon.com) near Wellsboro. The canyon runs along Pine Creek Gorge and measures 1,500 feet deep at some points. A strenuous one-mile hike leads into and out of the gorge. If you\u2019re not in a hurry to start the Route 2 crossing, begin by combing beaches and birding trails at Presque Isle State Park (presqueisle.org). Then take a quick jog northeast to visit the Roger Tory Peterson Institute in Jamestown, N.Y. (rtpi.org). It celebrates the life and career of the iconic artist, writer, and naturalist. And the nearby Audubon Community Nature Center (auduboncnc.org) is a great place to enjoy five miles of hiking trails through a 600-acre wetland preserve. \n \nSo when warmer weather returns, take Willie Nelson\u2019s advice and get \u201cback on the road again.\u201d \n \n*** \n \nScott Shalaway can be heard on Birds & Nature from 3 to 4 p.m. Sundays on 620 KHB Radio, Pittsburgh or live online anywhere at khbradio.com. Visit his website drshalaway.com or contact him directly at sshalaway@aol.com or 2222 Fish Ridge Road, Cameron, WV 26","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Society news","group":"Society"},{"name":"Opinion latest","group":"Society"}],"title":"The geography of hope in nature","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Wood","zipCode":"26101","state":"West Virginia","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Parkersburg","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"News and Sentinel","feed":{"genre":"Opinion","tags":[],"id":"169707085","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"287"},"name":"News and Sentinel","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Standard","Society"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.newsandsentinel.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695194361299","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:14:46Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

We, as citizens, need to stand by him and give him our allegiance and honor. This is America and this is the way things are done here. \n \nThe citizens have spoken and those who wanted someone else must accept the fact that there is one winner and one loser in any election. \n \nSome recent events have shamed our country and caused other nations to lose confidence in our way of government. No one group of persons is better or worse than any other group and the color of one\u2019s skin or being male or female doesn\u2019t give any group the right to think they are better than anyone else or to try to destroy our country. Riots never did any good to anyone and only show the ignorance of those destroying what does not belong to them. \n \nLet\u2019s hope and pray that we, as a nation, can get past this disobedience and become what we used to be, the example of being a noble nation. \n \nAs a citizen of the United States, this is what I believe. Laws have been made to help citizens live together in peaceful communities. I may not agree with all of them, but I will do my best to obey them. That is the duty of every citizen. \n \nThere are only ten basic laws that govern all mankind. These fundamental laws are the basis on which the laws of our country are based. Many thousands of patriots have given their lives to protect and keep America. It is the duty of every one of us to help keep her free. As a citizen, I pledge to honor and obey the laws of this country, honor our flag, support our leaders, and to support those who risk their lives to preserve our freedom. I am proud to be an American citizen. \n \nIt is important for the youth of our country to know the history of our country and the history of their ancestors. There has been a push to record the stories of fathers and grandfathers who were in World War II. \n \nTime is of an essence since that generation is thinning rapidly. It is traumatic for those who have faced the horrors of war to talk about it, and only decades after their experiences have many of them told their stories. It has been helpful for those in later years to record what they have experienced and it is what young folks today need to know about those who protect all of us. \n \nThe ancestors of all of us (except the Native Americans) came from somewhere else, and many of those came to this country because of war. The stories of how they became citizens and learned the language and culture of their new country are important for each family. The traditions they brought with them is part of our culture now. \n \nI met many folks in Europe when I lived there that told me what they, as children, went through during the war in their country. You do not want your children to have to face some of the horrors that they faced. I remember how scared I, as a child was, during World War II, and there was no fighting here in this country. We cannot let our county become so weak that anyone thinks they can \u201ctake us on\u201d and create war on our shores. \n \nWe need to let our young family members learn what their ancestors had to endure to become citizens in a strange land so that they can prevent harm on our shores as they become the governing age. Educate them in the traditions of your family. Leave them with journals of your life and the recipes of their grandmothers. Teach them the morays of family life so that they will have a contented and happy life. There is so much hate and violence in our world today that we have to show them that there is a better way to live. We need to show, by example, that no one should tolerate lawlessness and violence, or the loss of our freedom and our country. They need to learn to be Americans, as there is so much against our way of life at the present time, and much of it is internal. \n \nThe recipes today are for comfort foods. We all need them, especially, when we feel depressed and worry about our country. Pray for our president. And, add to your prayer list all those who protect us, those who need a \u201chelping hand.\u201d \n \nMay God Bless you and God Bless America. \n \n*** \n \nBAKED CUSTARD \n \n3 large (or 4 smaller) eggs \n \n1/3 cup sugar \n \n1 teaspoon vanilla extract \n \nPinch of salt \n \n2 1/2 cups warm milk (120 to 130 degrees) \n \nGround nutmeg \n \nBeat eggs, sugar, vanilla, and salt in medium bowl. Gradually add milk. Pour into custard cups or a casserole baking dish and sprinkle with nutmeg. Bake in preheated 350-degree oven for about 30 minutes for custard cups or 45 minutes for baking dish. Custard is done when a knife inserted between center and edge of dish comes out clean. Cool before serving and keep leftovers in refrigerator. \n \nNOTE: I never bother to warm the milk although most recipes mention doing it. Many recipes recommend setting the cups or baking dish in a larger pan and adding hot water to the pan, up to the level of the custard, for the baking process. I tried it once and nearly scalded myself when I splashed the hot water on myself while taking the baked dish out of the oven. I am clumsy, so I don\u2019t bake custard with a surrounding hot water bath and they come out fine and without the chance of hot water cascading over me and the kitchen floor. \n \nMy \u201cnever measure\u201d recipe is \u2014 per each cup of milk; 2 eggs, 2 tablespoons sugar, 1/2 to 1capful of vanilla, pinch of salt and nutmeg sprinkled on top and baked in moderate oven. \n \n*** \n \nGRANDMA NICHOLS\u2019 STOVE-TOP RICE PUDDING \n \n1 quart milk \n \n1 teacupful (about 3/4 measuring cup) uncooked rice \n \n1 large egg \n \n1/2 cup sugar \n \n2 full capfuls (2 teaspoons) vanilla extract \n \nPinch salt \n \nGround nutmeg or cinnamon \n \nWarm milk, in medium size saucepan, over low to medium heat and stir in rice as soon as milk starts to warm up. Bring to a simmer and cook, uncovered and stirring frequently, until the rice is very tender, about 30 to 35 minutes. In a bowl, beat the egg and add sugar, vanilla and salt. Gradually add the cooked rice to the egg mixture until well blended, and then return all to the saucepan. Cook and stir for a minute or two to cook the egg. Pour into custard cups or serving dish and sprinkle with nutmeg or cinnamon. Refrigerate until chilled. \n \n*** \n \nTAPIOCA PUDDING \n \n1 quart milk (4 cups) \n \n1/2 cup sugar \n \n3 large eggs \n \n1/4 teaspoon salt \n \n1/4 cup Minute tapioca \n \n1 teaspoon vanilla extract \n \nGround nutmeg \n \nIn a heavy saucepan, beat well the eggs, sugar, and salt together. Add the milk, vanilla and tapioca granules and let set for a few minutes to let the tapioca start to soften. Over medium high heat, bring the mixture almost to a boil, stirring constantly. When the mixture starts to show a slow boil and is thickening, remove from the heat. Pour into a serving bowl to cool and sprinkle with ground nutmeg. It can also be eaten warm. \n \n*** \n \nRHUBARB CUSTARD PIE \n \n3 cups cut up rhubarb \n \n1 1/2 cups sugar \n \n2 eggs, beaten \n \n2 tablespoons flour \n \nZest of 1/2 lemon \n \nJuice of 1/2 a lemon \n \n2 unbaked crusts for 10-inch deep dish pie \n \nMix rhubarb, sugar, eggs, flour, lemon zest and lemon juice. Fit one crust into pie pan and sprinkle bottom with a little addition flour. Fill shell with rhubarb mixture. Cut second crust into strips and make a lattice top for the pie. Brush the lattice strips with a little cream or milk or beaten egg wash and sprinkle with sugar. Bake in preheated 450-degree oven for 10 minutes, and then reduce heat to 350-degrees and bake until knife inserted in pie comes out clean, about 45 to 50 minutes. Cool on wire rack. Serve with a dip of good Vanilla Ice Cream. \n \n*** \n \nFRESH STRAWBERRY PIE w/CREAM CHEESE \n \n1 graham cracker pie crust \n \n1 quart fresh strawberries \n \n1 (8-ounce) package cream cheese \n \n1/4 cup sugar \n \n2 teaspoons lemon juice \n \n1/2 cup heavy whipping cream \n \n1 package strawberry glaze \n \nWhipped topping (or more whipping cream, whipped and sweetened) \n \nWash strawberries and cut into halves or smaller if the berries are large. Let the cream cheese come to room temperature. With electric mixer, beat cream cheese, sugar and lemon juice until well mixed. Add whipping cream and beat until light and fluffy. Spread in piecrust. Top with strawberries, then the glaze. Frost pie with the whipped topping (or the additional whipping cream, whipped and sweetened, if calories are not a problem). Use a large decorating star tube to add this \u201cmeringue\u201d , if available. Keep chilled. \n \n*** \n \nAPPLE CAKE \n \n11/4 cups sifted flour \n \n1 teaspoon baking powder \n \n1/4 teaspoon salt \n \n1 tablespoon sugar \n \n1/2 cup butter \n \n1 egg yolk, beaten \n \n2 tablespoon milk \n \n3 cups sliced apples \n \nMix and sift flour, baking powder, salt and sugar. With an electric mixer, in mixer bowl, cream butter, then add dry ingredients and mix. Combine egg yolk and milk and add to butter mixture and mix. Press this mixture on bottom of a buttered 8- x 8-inch pan. Overlap apple slices on top of this dough. \n \nSprinkle with topping and bake in preheated 375-degree oven for about 50 minutes. \n \nTOPPING: \n \n3/4 cup sugar \n \n1 1/2 tablespoons flour \n \n1/4 teaspoon cinnamon \n \n2 tablespoons butter \n \n1/4 teaspoon lemon zest \n \nMix sugar, flour, lemon zest and cinnamon. Cut in butter until it is like coarse cornmeal. \n \n*** \n \nPatty Christopher is a longtime columnist for the Parkersburg News and Sentinel.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Consumer: recipes","group":"Lifestyle"},{"name":"Society news","group":"Society"},{"name":"Opinion latest","group":"Society"}],"title":"Comfort foods are back for the family","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Wood","zipCode":"26101","state":"West Virginia","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Parkersburg","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"News and Sentinel","feed":{"genre":"Opinion","tags":[],"id":"169707085","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"287"},"name":"News and Sentinel","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Standard","Society"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.newsandsentinel.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695194361571","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:14:47Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

Overdose death caused by narcotic prescriptions have nearly quadrupled since 1999. From 1999 to 2014 the number of prescription related deaths exceeded more than 165,000 people \u2014 three times the number of U.S. military deaths from the Vietnam War. The numbers of overdose prescription pain medication deaths has risen in every county of every state reaching a new peak in 2014 at 78 deaths per day or three per hour. Simply put, the current health care treatment policies fail the very people seeking help. \n  \nIn a bold and pioneering move, the St. Joseph\u2019s Regional Hospital in Paterson, N.J., recently announced it has become the first hospital in the country to implement a program that will manage patients\u2019 pain in the emergency room with integrative care and without narcotic painkillers. Painkillers most frequently used in the emergencies rooms are OxyContin, Vicodin, and Percocet, according to Dr. Mark Rosenberg, the Emergency Department Chair. Dr. Andrew McLachlan, professor of the University of Sydney, reported narcotic use for chronic pain control exceeding three months has no clear studies, yet one point is understood, these medications do have harmful side effects including addiction and death. \n \nAnswers to address this public crisis are currently available, but not utilized to their fullest potential here in the Mid-Ohio Valley or the surrounding counties. Here is what we know when the public has greater access to chiropractic services: cost savings of 40 percent; back surgeries when choosing a surgeon occurred 42.7 percent versus 1.5 percent when going to a chiropractor first; reduced disability, 9.1 out of 10 patients reporting satisfaction with care, and most of all, saving lives. \n \nIt is time for an open and honest forum between the medical and chiropractic communities. We must put aside past harmful and deceptive rhetoric and work to integrate services that best serve the public. Discussion and demonstration for improved access of chiropractic services in the emergency rooms, pain management facilities, and physician offices is a great first step. Let us start now to reduce our drug epidemic for the love of the patients and public we all work to serve. \n \nByron Folwell \n \nParkersburg","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Society news","group":"Society"},{"name":"Opinion latest","group":"Society"}],"title":"Alternate pain care","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Wood","zipCode":"26101","state":"West Virginia","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Parkersburg","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"News and Sentinel","feed":{"genre":"Opinion","tags":[],"id":"169707085","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"287"},"name":"News and Sentinel","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Standard","Society"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.newsandsentinel.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695194362670","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:14:47Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

HART","domains":["PEO"],"score":"79"}],"wordCount":"507","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395769915&p=2kx&v=1&x=06S7EfuIpS6o0fKCLdacYw","id":"29395769915","content":"Comedian Keith Wann owned the stage in the Burlington-Edison High School auditorium \u2014 jumping, dancing and emoting his way to laughs from the audience. \n\nBut most of the time, Wann was silent. \n\nThough Wann can hear and speak, his first language \u2014 and the language in which he performs \u2014 is American Sign Language. \n\n\"I say English is my second language, even though I'm a hearing person,\" said Wann, who is the son of two deaf parents. \"That's my goal is to bring these two worlds together.\" \n\nWann, a California native now living in Brooklyn, was brought to Burlington-Edison by the school's Happy Hands ASL Club. \n\n\"He's like the Kevin Hart of the deaf world,\" said Happy Hands Club member Abbey Maroney, a sophomore. \"He's really famous.\" \n\nSome of Wann's jokes \u2014 like unplugging the vacuum while his mother was using it to see how long it would take her to notice \u2014 resonate more with the deaf community than with the hearing community, he said. \n\nBy drawing from his own experiences, he is able to give the speaking and hearing ASL students a glimpse of life as a deaf or hard-of-hearing person, reported the Skagit Valley Herald (http://bit.ly/2kknpM1). \n\n\"It's a great way to share culture,\" he said. \n\nEarlier in the day, Wann spoke with ASL students, who were thrilled to have him around. \n\n\"(Having Wann is) such a big deal for our school and our club,\" junior Jayla Dunn said. \n\n\"And also our town,\" junior Jenica Medina chimed in. \n\nWhile Burlington-Edison High School has no deaf students, Dunn said she became interested in learning sign language to be able to communicate with more people. \n\n\"I was really excited to be able to make conversation with such a diverse population,\" she said. \"You can always have them lip read, but it's such a deeper connection when you speak the same language. \n\nFor Wann, the students' excitement is a sign of change. He remembers the stigma his parents faced while he was growing up. \n\n\"Now it's cool,\" he said. \"If I was a teenager now, I'd get a lot more dates than I did in the '80s.\" \n\nDuring his 20 years as a performer, Wann's parents have remained an inspiration for his comedy show, he said. \n\n\"I feel like I want to sign in case my parents ever came to a show,\" he said. \n\nWhile his wife has served as his speaking interpreter for his comedy shows, Wann said he also often has local people \u2014 such as Happy Hands adviser Liza Bancroft \u2014 interpret sign language into speech. \n\n\"He's so well-respected and well-known in the deaf community,\" Bancroft said. \"So it's a real unique opportunity.\" \n\nOpportunity awaits the students continuing their ASL education as well, Wann said. \n\n\"You are learning our language,\" Wann signed during his show. \"You have two choices: You can use that language to help deaf people ... or you can use it to hurt them. I know you guys want to use it to help. Really, I hope some of you become interpreters, or maybe lawyers. Or maybe you'll work at McDonald's.\"","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"KERA WANIELISTASkagit Valley Herald"},"topics":[{"name":"Entertainment: latest","group":"Entertainment"},{"name":"US news","group":"Regional"}],"title":"Comedian brings American Sign Language to the stage","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"York","zipCode":"29730","state":"South Carolina","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Rock Hill","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Rock Hill Herald","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169657448","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"1027"},"name":"Rock Hill Herald","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Arts","Consumer"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.heraldonline.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":["http://bit.ly/2kknpM1"],"sequenceId":"695194364719","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T07:06:05Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:14:49Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

Psychobabblers speculate that low self-esteem can drive an individual to achieve great heights as a way to show the world, and himself, that he's not as worthless as he thinks he is in his heart of hearts. It also can motivate someone to act in bizarre ways just to get attention and to deflect for another instant one's intense self-doubt. If he's in a position to influence people's lives, he's not only self-destructive; he can cause a lot of misery. \n \nYou know where I'm going with this: straight to Donald Trump. Even becoming president of the United States and being the constant center of attention while doing all that cool chief-executive stuff that presidents get to do doesn't seem to fill his egotistical black hole. So he can be counted on to nurse his wounds by hiding them behind repeated grandiose claims that he would have won the popular vote were it not for the millions of people who fraudulently cast ballots against him. Never mind that the evidence is overwhelmingly against that; he's doubling down by saying he'll commission some sort of investigation. Of course, there's that self-demeaning bitter battle with \"dishonest media\" over the size of his inaugural crowd. It's a constant embarrassment to those around him, but he just won't let it go. \n \nThe list goes on and on: He can't stop himself from picking fights over past grudges and slights. It's easy to conclude, frankly, that the leader of the free world has mental problems. But perhaps it's more insidious than that. Maybe he and his aides are putting out this outlandish pettiness to mask the substantive steps he's taking to abandon all civility and to dismantle the federal government's ability to protect its citizens. Where do we start? His executive orders aim to gut regulation enforcement, sabotage health care, withdraw from or reshape trade deals, build that ridiculous wall, yada, yada, yada. \n \nExcept these are not yada, yada, yadas. Each time these major attacks on the nation's structures or international structures occurs, the president becomes a petty Twitter tyrant, tweeting something so ridiculous that it takes the focus off the poorly thought-out, destructive actions he's taking. So maybe he's not such a nutcase at all. Maybe he and his posse are just master media manipulators. \n \nDonald Trump occupies the White House because he played those of us in newsbiz while his opponent frittered her claim to history away in the fog of boredom. So what we see here is either someone who is crazy as a loon or someone who is presiding over an administration that constantly outmaneuvers the best efforts of journalists to challenge him. It should be noted that these are not mutually exclusive. Maybe he is diabolically that clever, even while he constantly battles with his emotional demons. He certainly wouldn't be the first one in history. \n \nThe only hope might be that the United States of America was not set up to be governed by one man who could snap his fingers and get things done. He usually has to get things past Congress. That being said, \"political courage\" is a huge oxymoron. The members of Congress, even President Trump's fellow Republicans, have their fingers in the air always testing the winds, which might start to shift as the damage from his decisions and impulsive actions become more obvious. He also will have to deal with an emboldened opposition, which has its collective finger in the air, too. \n \nSo eventually, this may come crashing down on Fragile Donald. Eventually. After attending Hemlock School in Eau Claire County, she graduated from Mondovi (Wis.) High School in 1954. She attended Eau Claire Vocational School (now Eau Claire Technical College), then was employed by General Casualty Company of Wisconsin in its Eau Claire office. She married the Rev. William H. Bearson on March 1, 1958, at Calvary Baptist Church in Eau Claire. They had three children. The couple served churches in Albertville, Wisconsin, Easton, Missouri, and Minneapolis. She taught Sunday school for many years and played piano and organ in the churches they served. While in the Minneapolis area she worked as a word processor for Pako Corporation, then as executive secretary for the chairman of the board and the chief financial officer of Pako. Later she worked in human resources. In 1983, she began working for Berkley Risk Administrators in Minneapolis and retired in 2001. \n   \nAfter retirement she moved to Alexandria, where in 2003 she married Ronald L. Aken, a retired Air Force senior master sergeant. They wintered for several years in Arizona City, where she played the organ at Arizona City Evangelical Methodist Church. They enjoyed the fellowship of many new friends during those years. She also enjoyed music, reading, crocheting, backyard bird watching and, most of all, spending time with her children and grandchildren. \n   \nWilliam Bearson died in 1996, and Ronald Aken died in 2010. She is survived by her daughter and two sons, Barbara J. Bell, Bradley W. and Robert F. Bearson; nine grandchildren; eight great-grandchildren; and four stepchildren, Robert Aken of Fargo, North Dakota, Ronald Craig Aken of Bear Lake, British Columbia, Canada, Roland Patterson of Wheatland, California, and Ronna Steffen of Sturgeon Lake, Minnesota, and their families. \n   \nMemorials may be sent to: Friends of Israel Gospel Ministry, P.O.
