But, still, in the middle of the locker room, the biggest reasons why the Clippers suffered their worst loss of the season were printed in easy to read letters. \n \nLong after the Golden State Warriors beat the Clippers 144-98, the white board \u2014 where the game plan is scribbled before each game \u2014 four two-word sentences were the only words not erased. \n \n\u201cPlay hard. Play smart. Play together. Have fun.\u201d \n \nThey\u2019re written there every game, and Saturday, they\u2019d never been ignored more. \n \n\u201cI agree,\u201d the Clippers\u2019 DeAndre Jordan said. \u201cWe\u2019ve got to figure it out because if not, we\u2019re going home early.\u201d \n \nThat Jordan is reflecting on the team\u2019s fate in April while the calendar still says January perfectly encapsulates the Clippers\u2019 issues against the Golden State Warriors \u2014 issues that couldn\u2019t have been easier to see if the team wore highlighter-green uniforms. \n \nAgainst the Warriors, everything seems bigger and more important because the Warriors \u2013 the NBA\u2019s best team \u2013 are better. \n \nThe Clippers\u2019 wins over San Antonio or Cleveland don\u2019t mean a thing inside Oracle Arena, where Golden State\u2019s beaten the Clippers 10 straight times. Against the Warriors (who have now won the last eight meetings between the two, no matter the venue), the Clippers just freeze. \n \n\u201cYou want it to so bad, you almost psyche yourself out of it,\u201d Blake Griffin said. \n \nIt\u2019s why Austin Rivers unleashed a few four-letter words when asked if the Warriors hold a mental edge over his team. It\u2019s why two early fouls to Griffin feels like a death sentence. It\u2019s why the first pass that sails into the seats seems to lead to another and another. And, it\u2019s why each Golden State basket \u2013 and boy, do these guys make baskets \u2013 feels like it\u2019s worth two or three times the points it puts on the scoreboard. \n \n\u201cThe mistakes kind of build,\u201d J.J. Redick said. \u201cAs they take advantage of it, it becomes like an avalanche. You saw that at the end of the first half.\u201d \n \nThe Warriors scored 17 points in 2 minutes and 38 seconds to close the second quarter, a stretch Redick described as \u201csome (expletive)\u201d that happened. \n \nStephen Curry, who scored 25 of his 43 points in the third quarter, closed the first half by sinking a one-footed jumper from beyond midcourt to beat the buzzer. \n \nWhile it\u2019s hard to simulate stopping Curry, the Clippers had the NBA equivalent to a bye week \u2014 three days off \u2014 to prepare. But once they got on the court, all the work and preparation simply got erased. \n \n \n\u201cA loss like this, it\u2019s made a lot worse with the type of effort we gave in stretches. {"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T06:45:37Z","duplicateGroupId":"29395771677","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"MUSLIMS & ISLAM","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"SOCIAL MEDIA","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"65"},{"name":"PASSPORTS & VISAS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"75"},{"name":"RELIGION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"68"},{"name":"IMMIGRATION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"91"},{"name":"EMIGRATION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"75"},{"name":"AIRPORTS","domains":["IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"RELIGIOUS DISCRIMINATION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"68"},{"name":"PROTESTS & DEMONSTRATIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"STUDENT ACTIVISM","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"PHYSICIANS & SURGEONS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"61"},{"name":"EXECUTIVE ORDERS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"75"},{"name":"PROFESSIONAL WORKERS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"87"},{"name":"POLICE FORCES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"60"},{"name":"DEPORTATION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"88"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; NEW YORK, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"UNITED STATES","domains":["GEO"],"score":"96"},{"name":"NEW YORK, NY, USA; UNITED STATES; NEW YORK, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"EGYPT","domains":["GEO"],"score":"92"}],"wordCount":"732","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395771677&p=2kx&v=1&x=wVXOaNEOpo_r4yXOd4jXYw","id":"29395771677","content":"Meanwhile Trump said his ban was \u2018working out very nicely\u2019 \n  \nProtesters gathered in the piercing cold at JFK and chanted late into the night. \n \n\u201cThis is bullshit,\u201d says Sabrine Atta, an 18-year-old student at Kent State. She was visiting family in New York when she heard news of the protest at JFK, and decided to join. \n \nTheir reason for being here, President Trump\u2019s executive order prohibiting the citizens of seven countries from entering the US, even if they have visas giving them the right to live and work here. \n \nThe order, which has been denounced as \u201c an affront to human dignity ,\u201d sparked airport protests across the nation as returning travelers found themselves thrown off their flights , detained and then deported. \n \nAll photos by Charlie Capel \n  \nStanding outside Terminal 4 holding a banner reading \u201cpeaceful Muslim,\u201d Sabrineexplained her fear of her place in America. \n \n\u201cI\u2019m scared. Definitely. America was built on immigration. And a lot of Muslims do good, they work in America as lawyers, doctors, engineers.\u201d \n \nSabrine says she\u2019s noticed a rise in anti-Muslim sentiment since the election. \n \n\u201cMy house has been egged. I\u2019ve deleted my Twitter and other social media because people would threaten me, saying I was an extremist and a radical Muslim.\u201d \n \nAnd how do her immigrant friends feel? \u201cThey\u2019re really scared. Their parents are immigrants. My grandmother\u2019s an immigrant, my grandfather\u2019s an immigrant.\u201d \n \n\u201cWe\u2019re all immigrants,\u201d chimes in a protester next to Sabrine, who\u2019s been listening. \u201cAmerica is a nation of immigrants.\u201d \n \nSabrine nods. As for the future of Trump\u2019s presidency, she plans to keep protesting. \u201cI hope this continues for four years. I hope it does not die down. We have to resist as much as we can.\u201d \n \n\n \nCarlos Jesus Calzadilla, 19, a student activist, says he is here on behalf of a friend. \u201cBefore coming here, one of my Muslim friends almost broke down in tears because he got a call from his mom telling him not to go out here. I told him, I\u2019m going to out there for you. It really touched me.\u201d \n \nStanding nearby is Bouhaitha Yousef, an Egyptian-American studying medicine. She\u2019s here with her mom, a practicing physician who emigrated from Egypt. Both are wearing the hijab. \n \nLike Sabrine, Bouhaitha is worried she too could be deported. \n \n\u201cIt\u2019s terrifying,\u201d she says. \u201cIf I hadn\u2019t been born in Queens, I wouldn\u2019t be able to get an education that would allow me to pay back this country. We came here for a better life. This is what makes America great.\u201d \n \nHer mom agrees. \u201cI came to this country as a professional, and I\u2019m raising a professional.\u201d \n \nBouhaitha and her mom \n  \nThe police in riot gear start pushing protesters off the road and onto the sidewalk, shunting people back with an orange barrier. \n \nStanding to the side of the mass is Khurram Mehtabdim, a young Pakistani doctor working in New York. Discussing the executive order, he says: \u201cIt\u2019s the most un-American thing I\u2019ve ever heard of. My ethnic background is not important. My family are all worried, it\u2019s a tough time.\u201d \n  \nBy the police at #JFKTerminal4  @TheTab  pic.twitter.com/Rw4bYKezeg \n \n\u2014 Harry Shukman (@HShukman) January 29, 2017 \n  \nNuzat, a master\u2019s student also from Pakistan, feels like her family had a lucky escape from the travel ban. By 12.30am she had carted her seventh Daphne Akhurst trophy back outside, to squeeze in one last pose for the photographers.\n\nBy lunchtime on Sunday she was on her way home; the tennis circus doesn't pause for record holders or even let them get much sleep. \"I'm leaving,\" said Williams, asking if she would stick around for Federer v Nadal. \"Man, I got to watch that match.\"\n\nFans were ready for Williams to win her 23rd grand slam title, and break her tie with Steffi Graf. They had been ready for a while.\n\nSerena wore red and black Nike Jordan boots featuring the No. 23 for the post-match presentation (you can also buy them in pink), Berlei had a new ad ready to run on social media and straight after the match Williams signed a set of gold racquets made by Wilson, strung to her specifications and featuring a 24-carat trapdoor on the butt cap. On sale for $960, with all proceeds headed for her foundation. All 23 were sold online within minutes.\n\nNone of this is to say that Serena is done, or satisfied. Graf was 30 when she retired, fresh off her first grand slam finals in three years at Roland Garros and Wimbledon in 1999, but with a hamstring injury and a lost love for the sport. Williams was 35 when she beat her older sister Venus on Saturday night, and plans to enjoy this one. \"It's a great number. I know she would like to have a little more,\" said Venus, while Serena conceded that it had sat somewhere at the back of her mind since she was 22.\n\n\"I guess after Wimbledon,\" said Williams, who went on to lose her US Open semi-final to Karolina Pliskova last year. Those Nikes had been sitting in a cupboard somewhere since. \"I obviously was thinking, 'OK, the next one.' I got it so fast, it didn't stay on the radar so long.\"\n\nSo is No. 24 \u2013 the Margaret Court pre-Open era record \u2013 just around the corner? \"No,\" said Williams. She hasn't forgotten: it took a year and three tough losses to creep from 21 up to 22. \"One thing I learned in the past is you have to enjoy it. That's the beauty of winning Australia, you have a few months to relax. If you win the French it's like back-to-back-to-back. Australia, you have time to enjoy the moment before the next grand slam.\"\n\nWilliams met Court in Perth last year for a \"really interesting\" chat, but grew up watching Graf, Monica Seles, Pete Sampras and can remember feeling inspired as a nine-year-old by Zina Garrison's run to the Wimbledon final. Now she knows that she, Graf and Navratilova are \"hands down leading the conversation\" when it comes to talk about which player is the greatest of all time.\n\n\"Yeah, just one thing about a champion, they keep fighting, they keep going,\" she said. \"I just feel like those four really are incredible fighters. They're mentally tough as well. They always kept going. It's something that I learned from them a lot, is how to hopefully do the same, which hopefully I've been able to do.\"\n\nSo what's next. A \"Serena Slam\"? Nope. \"A Serena Slam doesn't start in Australia,\" Williams said. \"It starts any other Grand Slam outside of Australia.\"\n\nA regular 'slam? \"I don't think about that either.\" How about one of the best-ever sporting stories to tell? Venus can answer that one for her. \"I don't think we're going for the greatest story in sports,\" she said. \"We're just going for some dreams. The manager is evidently unhappy with the options at his disposal and is looking to add a few players to the squad and the latest name extensively linked with a move to Liverpool is Bayer Leverkusen winger Julian Brandt. \n \nThe 20-year old is one of the most exciting talents in German domestic circuit at the moment and Jurgen Klopp\u2019s Liverpool are ready to pounce on him in the summer. But who is this new guy on the Anfield radar? Here is a peek into his scout report: \n \nBorn and bought in Bremen, Germany, the 6ft 1in started his youth career at SC Borgfeld, as a 5-year-old and only moved to the Bundesliga back in 2011 with Wolfsburg. He created waves at the academy in Wolfsburg and even before he could make a senior appearance for the side, he was snapped up by fellow Bundesliga outfit Bayer Leverkusen back in 2014. \n \nHe stayed in the junior side for 6 months and broke into the first team in the 2014-15 season making a super start to his senior club career. He now has 80 league appearances and at his age and is easily one of the best young players around in his position. \n \n\n \nCapable of playing in every position in the final third, the 20-year old is a smart winger, who is a goal scoring threat in most positions he plays. His vision, technique and passing ability make him a superstar for his age while his pace and ability to get past the opponents only makehim more dangerous. \n \nHe loves to take on his man in danger areas but is equally adept at finding his teammates in space in the final third. He is a player who will improve most squads in Europe as at his age, as he is only getting better performance after performance. \n \nThe winger loves to help his side out by dropping back when needed but he is at his best when he tries to go beyond his team\u2019s striker to create havoc among the back line of the opposition. However, he is not the strongest player in the air and could be a liability if he fails to work on that part of his game. He is also not the best finishers around but that is something he can learn with the more time he gets at the highest level. \n \nAt just 20, he is already capped at the international level for Germany and is a player who is destined for great things and Jurgen Klopp will want to be the one helping him to those things. At Anfield, the likes of Sadio Mane and Sheyi Ojo are the only two recognized wingers and Brandt will surely add more width to the squad when needed. The \u201csanitised\u201d report was declassified recently by the Central Intelligence Agency (CIA). \n \nThe report, whose complete title is not entirely available as it is part deleted, was prepared on the basis of inputs available to the CIA till January 1986. \n \nThe very first sentence of the report\u2019s available (undeleted) page reads: \u201cPrime Minister Rajiv Gandhi faces at least an even chance of assassination before his tenure in office ends in 1989.\u201d It, however, later clearly said that \u201cassassination is the major near-term threat\u201d to him. \n \nOver five years later, Gandhi was assassinated at Sriperumbudur in Tamil Nadu on May 21, 1991. \n \nThe first section titled \u201cKey Judgments\u201d analyses and deliberates upon what likely scenario would emerge in the domestic and international political situation if there is a sudden change in leadership minus Rajiv Gandhi and the likely impact on India\u2019s relations with the US, the then USSR and the region. \n \nIt also dealt with the threats posed to Gandhi\u2019s life by various extremist groups at that time and the likely fallout of his murder. \n \n\u201cIf Gandhi fell to a Sikh or Kashmiri Muslim assassin, widespread communal violence probably would erupt even if strong preventive security measures \u2013 including deployment of Army and paramilitary troops across northern India \u2013 were taken by the Indian President \u2026\u2026(deleted),\u201d it said. \n \nInterestingly, it also names P V Narasimha Rao and V P Singh, who could be the \u201cinterim successor\u201d and \u201clikely candidates\u201d in case of sudden exit by Rajiv. Rao took over as the Prime Minister in 1991. \n \nIn a section, titled \u2018The Threat of Assassination: Stability in Jeopardy\u2019, the report says \u201cIn our view, there is at least an even chance in the next several years of an assassination, most likely by extremist Sikhs or disgruntled Kashmiri Muslims who have targeted Rajiv,\u201d besides \u201ca fanatical Hindu\u201d. \n \nSince a significant portion of this section is deleted, it is not clear whether Sri Lankan Tamil extremists were also dealt with in the analysis. However, another section deals in- depth with Rajiv\u2019s mediation efforts to resolve \u201cthe conflict between militant Sri Lankan Tamils and the Sinhalese-dominated government in Colombo\u2026\u201d (More) \n \nThis is published unedited from the PTI feed.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"Press Trust of India"},"topics":[{"name":"India news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"US news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"US security news","group":"Society"}],"title":"\u2018CIA assessed Rajiv assassination 5 yrs before he was killed\u2019","source":{"category":"National","location":{"region":"Asia","subregion":"Southern Asia","countryCode":"IN","country":"India"},"editorialRank":"3","name":"India.com","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"597540856","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"0"},"name":"India.com","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Geographic","National","Standard","News"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.india.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695194420182","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T07:12:08Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:15:18Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[{"url":"http://s3.india.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/06/indiacom-image-banner_02.jpg"}],"video":[]}}

READ: It's a final that nobody saw coming but after the early exits of Andy Murray and Novak Djokovic, the old rivals have seized their opportunity with both hands.\n\nFor Federer, it's a chance to extend his all-time record tally of Grand Slam wins to 18 and exact a measure of revenge on his long-time nemesis.\n\nNadal can win his 15th Grand Slam title, closing the gap on Federer and drawing level with Pete Sampras in second place on the all-time list of major winners. READ: It comes after Serena and Venus Williams, aged 35 and 36 respectively, met in the women's final -- making it the first Open-era Grand Slam tournament where all four singles finalists have been in their thirties.\n\nLegendary clash between Federer and Nadal at Wimbledon 2008 Final \n\nNeither of the former world number ones was expected to reach the final after injuries disrupted their seasons last year and their rankings dipped, to 17 for Federer and nine for Nadal.\n\nFederer vs Nadal at Aus Open 2014\n\nThe unexpected reprise of one of tennis's great rivalries will be their ninth meeting in a major final, the most between any two players in the post-1968 Open era.\n\nNadal has won six of their major finals, with Federer's last victory was in 2007.\n\nBut the Spaniard said past results were irrelevant.\n\nMay the best man win\n\n\"It's a different match, different moment for both of us. I think this match is completely different than what happened before,\" he said.\n\n\"It's special. We have not been there in that situation for a while, so that makes the match different.\n\n\"I really don't think about what happened in the past. I think the player who plays better is going to be the winner.\"\n\nThe pair last contested a Grand Slam final at Roland Garros three years ago. They also met in the Australian Open semi-finals in 2014, with Nadal winning each time.\n\n\"Now it's a different time. A lot of time has gone by,\" Federer said. \"I know this court allows me to play a certain game against Rafa that I cannot do on centre court at the French Open.\"\n\nIt will be Federer's sixth Australian Open final and his 28th Grand Slam decider in total, and caps a marvellous comeback after the second half of last season was wiped out by a knee injury.\n\nHe has thrilled his many fans with his return, having not figured in a Grand Slam final since the 2015 US Open.\n\n\"This is the last one (match) so I will leave it all out here in Australia. {Even] if I cannot walk for another five months I will give it all I have,\" Federer said.\n\nHe can become the first man to win five or more titles at three Grand Slam events, while Nadal stands to become the only man in the Open era to win all the majors at least twice.\n\nAnyone else massively excited about this happening all over again!?? And Small Business Saturday was a busy day, said David Borlaug, president of the Lewis and Clark Fort Mandan Foundation, which runs the gallery.\n\n\"In spite of the bad weather, in terms of original art, sales have been great,\" he said. \"It validates Bismarck was ready for this kind of gallery.\"\n\nBorlaug said Bismarck has been \"blessed\" with a multitude of galleries, each with a different niche. Bismarck Downtown Artist Cooperative, Bismarck Art & Galleries Association and Gallery 522 all feature member artists' works. There's also Art Gallerie on Main, where Lydia Richez-Bowman features her own work and that of several other local artists, as well as teaching classes.\n\nBorlaug said Capital Gallery is focused on featuring two artists on its walls \u2014 one expressive and one traditional \u2014 along with several others who work in various other media, such as glass or bronze. The gallery sets itself apart by limiting the number of artists and featuring them for longer periods. And because it does not cater to member artists, \"the world's our oyster,\" he said.\n\nBorlaug has artists lined up for the foreseeable future, with Deane Collin Fay of Gackle alongside Bismarck native Vern Erickson's western Americana pieces coming up in Februarym The Bismarck Tribune (http://bit.ly/2joTPY3 ) reports.\n\n\"There is a thriving art culture in Bismarck,\" Borlaug said. \"We're just glad to be part of it.\"\n\nHe points to Jessica Wachter as an up-and-coming Bismarck artist who has a \"real following across the country,\" with works featured in galleries in Los Angeles and Scottsdale, Ariz.\n\nStephanie Delmore of Gallery 522 agrees.\n\n\"I think we're just getting to that point of there being enough galleries\" that they could partner on events, like gallery hops, she said. \"We can start to thread ourselves together.\"\n\nAs Bismarck's population has become more diverse, Delmore said there are more people who are used to going to galleries on a regular basis.\n\n\"I think the traffic is picking up,\" she said, with the public understanding what art adds to a community.\n\nSince starting 32 years ago, Gallery 522 has wanted all local artists to be able to show their work daily rather than wait five years for their turn at a larger show.\n\n\"We've always meant to be of service to artists,\" Delmore said, and on a day-to-day basis, the gallery has a multitude of artists covering its walls.\n\nBismarck Downtown Artist Cooperative works much the same way, though with slightly different rules and organization, while BAGA has become more well-known for hosting larger shows for its member artists, Delmore said.\n\n\"I think we've got a lovely base of artists in the area,\" she said, and having more galleries showcasing those artists could result in more art-focused events come spring.\n\nBorlaug said he thinks Bismarck is where Fargo was a couple decades ago in terms of growing from a big town to a small city \u2014 and art \"makes cities.\"\n\n\"I feel Bismarck is more than ready to grow its arts community,\" he said.\n\nIn turn, that community could help grow the city, attracting more residents. Borlaug said one of the first things people want to know about before moving somewhere is the arts scene: Is there a symphony? An orchestra? Visual arts?\n\n\"It could help get people to move here,\" he said, and the art produced here is helping tell this area's story.\n\n---\n\nInformation from: Bismarck Tribune, A US judge has issued a stay temporarily halting the deportation of visa holders or refugees under an executive order from President Trump. \n \nThe American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) filed a legal case early on Saturday in response to the order. \n \nThe judge's stay prevents those \"caught up\" in the aftermath from being deported, the ACLU said. \n \nThe group estimates that between 100 and 200 people were being detained at airports or in transit. \n \nThe court decision came as thousands protested at airports in several US states over Donald Trump's clamp down on immigration. \n \nHis executive order, signed on Friday, halted the entire US refugee programme and also instituted a 90-day travel ban for nationals from Iran, Iraq, Libya, Somalia, Sudan, Syria and Yemen. \n \nThose who were already mid-flight were detained on arrival - Mutasa Central MDC MP, Trevor Saruwaka, yesterday said House of Assembly speaker, Jacob Mudenda, has no right to determine the colour of clothes he wears in Parliament. \n \nIn October last year, Saruwaka was ejected from Parliament for wearing a jacket adorned with Zimbabwe\u2019s national flag colours. \n \nIn protest, he approached the High Court over the move, which created commotion in Parliament resulting in police intervention. \n \nSaruwaka argued in court yesterday that his ejection from Parliament for wearing the jacket was unlawful and an infringement of his right to freedom of conscience and religion. \n \nHe further said there was no provision in the Standing Rules and Orders of the Parliament that bars him from wearing such colours. \n \nIn the application, Saruwaka \u2013 who is represented by attorneys from Kadzere, Hungwe & Mandevere Legal Practitioners \u2013 cited Mudenda and the chief security officer of Parliament as respondents. \n \nSaruwaka said he is an avowed follower of the Rastafari religion, adding that the colours on his jacket are synonymous with his religion. \n \n\u201c\u2026it is respectfully submitted that, applicant (Saruwaka) being of the Rastafari religion, has a right to freedom of conscience and religion in terms of Section 60 of the Constitution, which right includes the right to propagate his religious beliefs whether in private or in public within the confines of the law. \n \n\u201cBy arbitrarily denying applicant access to Parliament, respondents have elevated themselves above the Constitution without lawful cause. There is no legal basis upon which applicant can be barred from entering Parliament,\u201d the court heard. \n \nHe said he is entitled to protection by the law. \n \n\u201cIt is further submitted that, respondents do not have the power to determine the colour of the jacket applicant wears. The respondents are therefore acting outside the scope of their powers by ejecting applicant from National Assembly sessions on account of wearing the jacket in question,\u201d he said. \n \nHe added that according to the provisions of Standing Order 76 (7), only jeans, T-shirts and sleeveless outfits, are prohibited from the House. \n \n\u201cNowhere is it mentioned that jackets such as the one worn by the applicant are prohibited,\u201d he said, adding that his jacket does not in any way offend the national flag. \n \nSaruwaka\u2019s Parliament \u201cdrama\u201d took place after Mudenda The Meteorological Services Department (Met) has advised that most parts of Zimbabwe will receive even heavier rains in the next three days. \n \nThe Department warned that the severe rains could cause severe flooding in low-lying areas. \n \nIts forecaster, John Mupuro, said \u201ceven more widespread rains are anticipated from Saturday 28 to Tuesday 31, January 2017, thus necessitating the need for warning\u201d. \n \n\u201cThe heavy rains that have started pounding almost everywhere in Zimbabwe are forecast to continue,\u201d he said, adding that people must take the flood warnings seriously. \n \n\u201cDespite these warnings and advisories, reports of drowning are a serious cause of concern,\u201d Mupuro said. \n \nThe forecaster added that rainfall in excess of 50 millimetres is expected in the next 24 hours. \n \nMupuro further highlighted that over areas on high ground, particularly along the central watershed and eastern highlands, rains in excess of 90 mm are a high probability in a day. \n \n\u201cThe present rainy situation is a combination of the presence of the Inter Tropical Convergence Zone and a frontal cloud system which entered the country from the Matabeleland province.\u201d \n \n\u201cAdded to this combination is the heating around midday which further enhances rainfall activity,\u201d Mupuro said in the forecast. \n \nThe Civil Protection Unit (CPU) has also warned people to be vigilant and know their weather forecast to avoid being caught up in bad weather. \n \nSo far, the Unit has warned that areas that have been hit by flash floods so far include parts of Guruve, Mt Darwin, Chitungwiza, Marange, Buhera, Mutasa, Bulilima, Mangwe and Victoria Falls. \n \n\u201cCivil Protection structures are responding in the different parts of the country. \n \n\u201cAssistance such as tents, clothing and other items are being provided on a need basis. Opposition secessionist party, Mtwhakazi Republic Party (MRP), will field local government and parliamentary candidates to challenge President Robert Mugabe\u2019s Zanu PF in the forthcoming key 2018 election. \n \nSince its formation three years ago, MRP had declared that it would not take part in any election in Zimbabwe as their mission was to withdraw the whole of Matabeleland and Midlands provinces from the southern African country and form a new separate and independent Mthwakazi State. \n \nBut in a surprise move, MRP leader Mqondisi Moyo told journalists after the party\u2019s third anniversary meeting that the decision to participate in the elections came from its members. \n \n\u201cDue to our consultations with people on the ground, we got the mandate that come 2018 to participate,\u201d Moyo said. \n \n\u201cOur motivation for participation is mainly centred on our Mthwakazi territory from Beitbridge to Zambezi from Plumtree to Midlands that is Munyathi River.\u201d \n \nMoyo said they will field candidates in wards and constituencies in Matabeleland and Midlands region. \n \n\u201cWe are not concerned much about contesting in Zimbabwe elections but we are concerned about Matabeleland and Midlands where our people are, that is where our interest is. \n \n\u201cThis will help us legitimise our struggle to show that we have people behind us, to prove to the entire world that we are indeed the party for the people of Matabeleland,\u201d he said. \n \nMoyo, however, said he was not going to stand as a presidential candidate come 2018. \n \n\u201cWe are not going to contest for the presidency because if we do that it will appear as if we are interested in governing Zimbabwe, yet that\u2019s not within our plans. If an economy has got less than 12 percent, it faces liquidity crisis\u2026..We need $900 million in cash to have adequate liquidity,\u201d said Chakravarti. \n \nHard cash circulation in the country has dropped by 53 percent from $642 million in 2013 to $304 million currently. However, bank deposits have increased from $4,728 billion in 2013 to $6,2 billion in 2016. \n \nAt the onset of the multicurrency system in February 2009, total deposits in the banking system were $1,66 billion. Cash to deposit ratio has decreased from 35 percent in 2009 to five percent in January 2017. \n \nThe amount of cash held in Nostro accounts declined by 61,6 percent from $424 million in 2009 to $163 million as at November 2016. \n \n\u201cWhen liquidity challenges first surfaced in 2014, the RBZ reduced cash holdings in Nostro accounts from 30 percent to 5 percent of total deposits to improve the availability of cash in the economy. This decision simply led to externalisation of dollar cash, exacerbating the liquidity crisis,\u201d said Chakravati. \n \nTo resolve the liquidity crisis in the country, Chakravarti recommended that the government should reduce wage bill, stop reissuing of Treasury Bills and borrowing from the private sector, repeal the indigenisation policy and adopt the South African Rand. \n \nThe business community has voiced its distrust of government methods of dealing with the acute cash shortage of bank notes and urged an adoption of the Rand, a suggestion the State turned down. \n \nChakravati has previously suggested a three percent import levy across the board which he said could raise $2 billion (annually) to incentivise exporters in real currency instead of the bond note incentive. \n \n[GoogleAd]","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[],"title":"Zim has only $300mln in circulation","source":{"category":"National","location":{"region":"Africa","subregion":"Eastern Africa","countryCode":"ZW","country":"Zimbabwe"},"editorialRank":"3","name":"Daily News Zimbabwe","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"427574606","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"11"},"name":"Daily News Zimbabwe","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Standard","News"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.dailynews.co.zw"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695194439644","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T08:37:28Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:15:27Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[{"url":"http://www.dailynews.co.zw/data/media/00002456/Original__zoom.jpg"}],"video":[]}}

ZIMBABWE","domains":["GEO"],"score":"73"},{"name":"ZIMBABWE","domains":["GEO"],"score":"92"}],"wordCount":"428","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395773296&p=2kx&v=1&x=fu24nQ_GtdbMDGUalf-ffw","id":"29395773296","content":"HARARE - Local retailers are struggling to remain profitable in the wake of acute cash shortages, an increasingly menacing informal sector and deteriorating economic conditions, the Confederation of Zimbabwe Retailers (CZR) said. \n \nCZR president Denford Mutashu told the businessdaily that with competition from the informal sector and cash shortages, the sector was on the verge of operating unprofitably. \n \n\u201cThe truth of the matter is the profit margins for most retailers are very low and they are struggling to just break even, let alone be profitable. \n \n\u201cMost retailers have tried to keep their mark-ups very low to retain as many customers as they can due to competition from the informal traders. They do not have the same overheads as the bigger players, so that is what most retailers are up against,\u201d said Mutashu, in a telephone interview. \n \nHe also said most were running promotions and avoiding price increases as a survival mechanism to stay afloat. \n \n\u201cIn fact, price increases are detrimental to retailers mainly because of the competition between informal and formal retailers. Consumers will walk away. \n \n\u201cRetailers do not increase prices, they are just a conduit and act on how manufacturers peg against supply and demand,\u201d the CZR president said. \n \nThis comes as food prices for basic food stuffs have gone up over the past few months as retailers reportedly put premium mark-ups on United States Dollar (US$) purchases. \n \nBeef is now sold at $7 per kilogramme (kg) from an average of $4,50 per kg in October while chicken reached the unprecedented price of $3,45 per kg. \n \nA 2-litre cooking oil bottle, which used to trade at $2,99 before the import restriction in June last year, now costs an average of $3,40. \n \nBattling a cash availability crisis, Zimbabwe has left consumers with very little choice but to transact using cash-lite methods. \n \nOver the past few months, cash-lite transactions have been going up with Mutashu saying this was the competitive advantage formal retailers had over their informal counterparts. \n \nHarare-based economist Issis Mwale said the country\u2019s economic meltdown was the reason prices were going up with retailers getting the short-end of the stick. \n \n\u201cThe retailer is not making the goods they are selling in most cases, they are just the link with the consumer. If the manufacturer fails to pay his supplier on time because there is no money in the nostro, then they get raw materials late and transfer that cost to the consumer whose fault is it? \n \n\u201cWhat we just need is economic reform before things get out of hand. \n \nBecause believe it or not, the retailers really have low mark-ups,\u201d Mwale said. \n \n[GoogleAd]","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"Ndakaziva Majaka"},"topics":[{"name":"Retail industry news","group":"Industry"}],"title":"Zim retailers struggle to remain profitable","source":{"category":"National","location":{"region":"Africa","subregion":"Eastern Africa","countryCode":"ZW","country":"Zimbabwe"},"editorialRank":"3","name":"Daily News Zimbabwe","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"427574606","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"11"},"name":"Daily News Zimbabwe","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Standard","News"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.dailynews.co.zw"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695194439931","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T08:43:41Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:15:27Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[{"url":"http://www.dailynews.co.zw/data/media/00007489/Original__zoom.jpg"}],"video":[]}}

While Zimbabwe may have gone out in the group stage, Billiat was one of their stars of the tournament, particularly impressive against Algeria, where he proved himself against defenders used to playing at the top level in European football,\u201d the Daily Mail said. \n \n\u201cAt 26, Billiat is probably too old to be signed as one for the future. There is reported interest from clubs in the French and Belgian top flights, but don\u2019t rule out a move to England down the line.\u201d \n \nBilliat has been outstanding for Sundowns, and was named the 2015-16 PSL Player of the Season in South Africa. \n \nNot only has the wonderfully-gifted forward terrorised PSL defences, but he also played a major role in helping Sundowns win the African Champions League and was voted only behind team-mate and Ugandan international keeper Denis Onyango in Caf\u2019s best-player-based in Africa awards. \n \nSamuel Kuffour, a European Champions League winner with Bayern Munich, and a pundit on SuperSport, also offered praise for Billiat after watching his first game against Algeria. \n \n\u201cI think Billiat is one of the best African talents I have seen in a long time. NIGERIA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"67"}],"wordCount":"437","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395773312&p=2kx&v=1&x=wSJsFL7wARe14rIuScNPMw","id":"29395773312","content":"HARARE - Winners of the national stage of the 2016 DStv Eutelsat Star Awards competition have been named, with students from schools in Harare, Mutare, Bulawayo and Chishawasha winning accolades for their entries in the poster and essay categories of the competition. \n \nAndile Dube, 18, of St Columba\u2019s High School, Bulawayo took the honours in the essay category with 16-year-old Ruvimbo Jongwe of St Dominic\u2019s High School in Chishawasha coming second. \n \nIn the poster category, Shaun Matondo, 16, of Hartzell High School in Mutare was named winner while 17-year-old Brandon Murira of Mutare Boys High School was the runner-up. \n \nMultiChoice Zimbabwe publicity and public relations manager Liz Dziva said the national champions will represent Zimbabwe against representatives from other countries. \n \n\u201cWe were delighted with the number of entries received for 2016 and judging of submissions from across Zimbabwe has now been completed. \n \n\u201cWe are pleased that the prize winners come from a number of schools across the country and we are hopeful that they will do well in competition against the other countries\u2019 national winners, as their submissions have now gone for consideration at international level,\u201d said Dziva. \n \nThe DStv Eutelsat Star Awards competition, sponsored by MultiChoice Africa and its satellite partner, Eutelsat, is open to students from secondary schools across Africa. \n \nIt seeks to promote knowledge and understanding of the role of satellites in communications technology. The competition is made up of poster and essay categories, with winners at country and continental level. \n \nSince the competition was launched in 2011, Zimbabwean students have fared well at international level with poster and essay sections having been won by Zimbabweans against stiff competition from peers across the continent. \n \nThe international level winners will be announced at a ceremony hosted by the competition sponsors in Lagos, Nigeria, on Tuesday, February 7. \n \nFemale astronaut Claudie Haignere, former astronaut and French minister, who is a special advisor to the European Space Agency director-general, will chair the jury for the DStv Eutelsat Star Awards in a move aimed at acting as a strong incentive for female students to live up to their full potential. \n All things being equal, we will have a rally at the airport next week when he returns from the African Union summit in Addis Ababa,\u201d the bigwig said. \n \nAnother senior party official corroborated the claim saying there had been real fears that there could have been a bloodbath at the airport if Mugabe\u2019s usual reception routines had not been changed. \n \n\u201cGushungo\u2019s (Mugabe\u2019s) travel arrangements were successfully kept a hush-hush affair, with only very few people in the know about when and how he would return. \n \n\u201cI think this was very smart of the president and his close lieutenants because anything could have happened today had the usual routines been followed, with large crowds of bickering supporters there,\u201d the official said. \n \nIndeed, there were neither the usual crowds of rank and file supporters, nor the large contingent of Cabinet ministers and other senior government officials and top securocrats who normally throng the airport to welcome the nonagenarian each time he leaves or returns home from his myriad trips. \n \nEven the police details who usually man all the capital city\u2019s major intersections and traffic lights, along his home route from the airport, were conspicuous by their absence. \n \nAccording to well-placed sources, Mugabe did not say much to the few officials who welcomed him upon his arrival, including vice president Emmerson Mnangagwa, telling them about his leave, as well as his State visit to China. \n \nOn Thursday, disaffected war veterans threatened to beat up ruling party supporters who belong to Zanu PF\u2019s Generation 40 (G40) faction who were planning to denounce Mnangagwa upon Mugabe\u2019s return. \n \nThe war veterans, who want Mnangagwa to succeed Mugabe, claimed that the G40 group, which is rabidly opposed to the Midlands godfather\u2019s ascendancy, was planning to transport thousands of party supporters to Harare International Airport, to not only welcome the nonagenarian and his family back, but to also humiliate Mnangagwa. \n \nAnother source who spoke to the Daily News last night also said it was in this light that intelligence operatives had deliberately sent the media and the warring Zanu PF factions on \u201ca wild goose chase\u201d about Mugabe\u2019s travel arrangements. \n \n\u201cIn the interests of everyone, it was felt that it was safer to confuse the warring factions and allow the president to arrive without facing this difficult situation of having to choose one faction over the other. \n \n\u201cSo, it was decided to do what we did for the sake of Gushungo and making sure that no faction would claim psychological victory in the raging succession wars,\u201d the senior Zanu PF official said. \n \nSpeaking on Thursday, kingpins and their supporters) that they are going too far. {"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T07:15:35Z","duplicateGroupId":"29384204859","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"LEGISLATIVE BODIES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"TAXICABS & LIMOUSINES","domains":["IND"],"score":"90"},{"name":"CITIES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"LICENSES & PERMITS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"72"},{"name":"PROTESTS & DEMONSTRATIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"58"},{"name":"REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"DEVELOPMENT BANKS","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"77"},{"name":"CITY GOVERNMENT","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"DRIVERS LICENSES","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"89"}],"wordCount":"832","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395774027&p=2kx&v=1&x=kpWhcCEOf4ERntFO7Xjxhw","id":"29395774027","content":"Comments(0)   \nThe drive towards a new points-based check system for taxi licensing in Derby is a \"hindrance to the whole trade\" and could result in a 31% increase in fares, according to a city car hire operator. \n \nShahid Quayum is also chairman of Alpha \u2013 All Licensed Private Hire Association \u2013 which he said is seeing increasing numbers of taxi drivers joining because they are concerned for their future ability to earn a living. He added that many of them wanted to mount an official protest. \n \nLabour-led Derby City Council wants to introduce the new system, which would see powers taken away from councillors and put into the hands of council officers, using a points-based system based on previous convictions, from June 30. \n \nIt will cost almost 140,000 to pay for five additional staff to run the system, which is meant to be self-funding and intended to stop rogue taxi drivers operating in Derby. \n READ MORE: How shock 138,500 for more staff could drive up taxi fees and fares  \nAccording to officers, \"any additional costs the council may incur in introducing some or all of the proposals, will need to be met by the trade\". \n \nThis has caused members of the council's licensing committee to question the new system and Mr Quayum said they are right to be concerned. \n \nHe said: \"Taxi drivers are having to work all hours now \u2013 sometimes up to 15 a day to make a decent living. But the extra cost of increased fees because of a new system they do not want will be the final straw for many of them. \n \n\"Others who do not want to pay the extra will go elsewhere to get licences, where there isn't a points-based system, ensuring that the council is powerless to stop rogue taxi drivers in Derby.\" \n \n\n \nThere are 1,300 drivers licensed with the city council but estimates suggest that there are around 2,800 working in the area, not licensed in Derby. \n \nMr Quayman said: \"The legislation only says that a taxi driver has to be a 'fit and proper person' to hold a licence. Those two things can be checked using a DBS (disclosure and barring check) and a medical. \n \n\"Two things will happen if this comes into force. One, taxi fares will go up from around 3.80 a mile to 5 and two, a possible 500 drivers will go elsewhere meaning that licence fees and fares could be even higher because the new system has been costed based on the current 1,300 licensed drivers.\" \n READ MORE: The new points-based system gets Derby City Council go-ahead last November  \nOne of the new posts would be 52,000 to pay for a lawyer because it was anticipated that the number of appeals against licence refusal would increase and have to go before magistrates to be defended. They said this had happened in Leicester, which has a similar system, leading to a 350% increase in appeals, according to council officers. \n \nThe points system was developed following a damning report stating failings in Derby City Council's taxi licensing system . Expert auditors found that the authority's taxi licensing sub-committee had allowed licences for people with criminal records who had committed offences including \"hate crime, harassment, intimidation and making improper comments to young women\". \n \nIn one instance, a taxi driver was granted a licence despite \"publishing material threatening or intending to stir up religious/sexual hatred\". In the new points-based system, criminal convictions for the most severe crimes including rape and murder will trigger an automatic lifetime disqualification. \n \n\n \nOther lesser crimes will accrue points on a sliding scale. Assault of a police officer, for example, would mean instant refusal for an applicant if it happened less than four years ago. But it would mean six points if committed five years ago, then five points for six years ago, four for seven years ago, and so on. \n \nAny applicant or existing driver who gets \"above 12 points\" would be disqualified. An alternative change would have seen council officers operate committees similar to the ones currently run by councillors. \n READ MORE: Tory pledge to reverse new system if they gain power on Derby City Council  \nMr Quayum added: \"We have polled our members and increasingly, it seems they want to take action and protest against the system. Many taxi drivers are very resentful but are suffering in silence.\" \n \nTory councillor Mick Barker said: \"It is now obvious that the extra costs, which will be passed on to the taxi trade, will raise serious concerns to drivers and operators alike and potentially cause them to register in cheaper authority areas - leaving Derby with limited control over taxi services.\" \n \n\"We are in danger of pushing drivers too far in demanding extra exacting standards and extortionate fees which will lead them to seek registration elsewhere. That being the case, it undermines the ability of the city council to administer standards on both vehicles and drivers, which is to the detriment of our public that both we and the taxi trade serves.\" \n OTHER NEWS: See what the late Derbyshire-born actor John Hurt had to say about Derby","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Political unrest EUROPE","domains":["GEO"],"score":"77"},{"name":"EUROPE","domains":["GEO"],"score":"91"}],"wordCount":"307","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395774109&p=2kx&v=1&x=XYQ1_C4fROG8s_m2tWQgkA","id":"29395774109","content":"New York, Jan 29 (PTI) Scientists have found a 38,000-year-old engraved art in a rockshelter \u2013 bearing the image of a wild cow surrounded by rows of dots \u2013 that offers a window into the lives of modern humans during the period. \n \n\u201cThe discovery sheds new light on regional patterning of art and ornamentation across Europe at a time when the first modern humans to enter Europe dispersed westward and northward across the continent,\u201d said Randall White, an anthropologist at the New York University, who led the excavation in France\u2019s Vezere Valley. \n \nThe findings centre on the early modern humans\u2019 Aurignacian culture, which existed from about 43,000 to 33,000 years ago. \n \nAbri Blanchard, the French site of the recently uncovered engraving, a slab bearing a complex image of an aurochs, or wild cow, surrounded by rows of dots, was previously excavated in the early 20th century. \n \nResearchers began their exploration of remaining deposits at the site in 2011, with the discovery occurring in 2012. \n \nAurignacian art offers a window into the lives and minds of its makers \u2013 and into the societies they created, White said. \n \n\u201cFollowing their arrival from Africa, groups of modern humans settled into western and Central Europe, showing a broad commonality in graphic expression against which more regionalised characteristics stand out,\u201d he said. \n \n\u201cThis pattern fits well with social geography models that see art and personal ornamentation as markers of social identity at regional, group, and individual levels,\u201d he added. \n \nAbri Blanchard and its sister site, Abri Castanet, previously excavated by White\u2019s team, have long been recognised as being among the oldest sites in Eurasia bearing artifacts of human symbolism. \n \nOver time, hundreds of personal ornaments have been discovered, including pierced animal teeth, pierced shells, ivory and soapstone beads, engravings, and paintings on limestone slabs. \n \nThe research appears in the journal Quaternary International. \n \nThis is published unedited from the PTI feed.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"Press Trust of The problem with CNG is there are no fueling stations. It would take a lot of money to build fueling stations,\u201d said Mike Pickens , executive director of the Office of School Transportation and School Facilities at the West Virginia Department of Education . \n \n\u201cIt\u2019s a very attractive product,\u201d he added. \u201cIt could be the best of all of them, but it\u2019s so expensive. There\u2019s no way to do a pilot (project) because there are no fueling stations.\u201d \n \nPropane companies will agree to build fueling stations at county bus garages in exchange for vehicle purchase contracts with those companies, so that reduces the cost of refueling infrastructure for counties considering the switch from diesel fuel to propane, Pickens said. \n \nLarry Fowler , director of school bus sales at Matheny Motors at Mineral Wells, said there also is the cost difference. A CNG bus can cost $35,000 more than a diesel bus, Fowler said. Matheny Motors offers buses from Thomas Built Buses that use CNG, but there has been no interest in West Virginia, he said. \n \nOne of the three domestic bus manufacturers began selling gasoline-powered buses this school year, and another has announced plans to do so. Schools nationwide moved away from gasoline in the 1980s because diesel engines were more durable and had better fuel economy than gasoline engines. With diesel engines becoming more complicated and requiring the use of an additive to reduce emissions, some school systems in the United States have asked manufacturers to consider building gasoline-powered buses. \n \nPickens said West Virginia accepts bids for diesel, propane and CNG buses, but not for gasoline. \n \n\u201cWe got away from gasoline a few years ago for several reasons,\u201d he said. \u201cIt\u2019s not even an acceptable fuel right now.\u201d \n \nHowever, the state is not ruling out gasoline in the future, he added.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Society news","group":"Society"},{"name":"Education news","group":"Society"}],"title":"Little Interest in W.Va. There's a very strong nexus between our immigration and visa programs and terrorist plots and extremist networks inside the United States,\" the official continued. \"Look at the recent, high-profile attacks that have occurred inside the country -- an immigration nexus is not at all uncommon. I won't go through the list of them all now. One obvious example would be Tashfeen Malik and the San Bernadino incident with the K1 visa.\" \n\nA K1 visa is a non-immigrant visa issued to the foreign-citizen fiance of a US citizen. Tashfeen Malik was from a family of wealthy landowners in Pakistan and later moved to Saudi Arabia with her immediate family. Her husband, Syed Rizwan Farook, was a US citizen. \n\nPakistan and Saudi Arabia, however, are not on the list of countries subject to the new ban. \n\nThe administration is facing criticism from leaders in the U.S. and around the world for taking steps their critics say are unconstitutional and anti-American. \n\nThe second mention of San Bernardino came when the official was trying to explain why there was no grace period before the executive order went into effect, to help ease implementation. \n\n\"Imagine if this had been an executive order that had been contemplated the day before the San Bernardino shooter entered the United States?\" the official asked. \"Would have delaying its implementation served the best interests of the country? And Small Business Saturday was a busy day, said David Borlaug, president of the Lewis and Clark Fort Mandan Foundation, which runs the gallery. \n\n\"In spite of the bad weather, in terms of original art, sales have been great,\" he said. \"It validates Bismarck was ready for this kind of gallery.\" \n\nBorlaug said Bismarck has been \"blessed\" with a multitude of galleries, each with a different niche. Bismarck Downtown Artist Cooperative, Bismarck Art & Galleries Association and Gallery 522 all feature member artists' works. There's also Art Gallerie on Main, where Lydia Richez-Bowman features her own work and that of several other local artists, as well as teaching classes. \n\nBorlaug said Capital Gallery is focused on featuring two artists on its walls \u2014 one expressive and one traditional \u2014 along with several others who work in various other media, such as glass or bronze. The gallery sets itself apart by limiting the number of artists and featuring them for longer periods. And because it does not cater to member artists, \"the world's our oyster,\" he said. \n\nBorlaug has artists lined up for the foreseeable future, with Deane Collin Fay of Gackle alongside Bismarck native Vern Erickson's western Americana pieces coming up in Februarym The Bismarck Tribune (http://bit.ly/2joTPY3 ) reports. \n\n\"There is a thriving art culture in Bismarck,\" Borlaug said. \"We're just glad to be part of it.\" \n\nHe points to Jessica Wachter as an up-and-coming Bismarck artist who has a \"real following across the country,\" with works featured in galleries in Los Angeles and Scottsdale, Ariz. \n\nStephanie Delmore of Gallery 522 agrees. \n\n\"I think we're just getting to that point of there being enough galleries\" that they could partner on events, like gallery hops, she said. \"We can start to thread ourselves together.\" \n\nAs Bismarck's population has become more diverse, Delmore said there are more people who are used to going to galleries on a regular basis. \n\n\"I think the traffic is picking up,\" she said, with the public understanding what art adds to a community. \n\nSince starting 32 years ago, Gallery 522 has wanted all local artists to be able to show their work daily rather than wait five years for their turn at a larger show. \n\n\"We've always meant to be of service to artists,\" Delmore said, and on a day-to-day basis, the gallery has a multitude of artists covering its walls. \n\nBismarck Downtown Artist Cooperative works much the same way, though with slightly different rules and organization, while BAGA has become more well-known for hosting larger shows for its member artists, Delmore said. \n\n\"I think we've got a lovely base of artists in the area,\" she said, and having more galleries showcasing those artists could result in more art-focused events come spring. \n\nBorlaug said he thinks Bismarck is where Fargo was a couple decades ago in terms of growing from a big town to a small city \u2014 and art \"makes cities.\" \n\n\"I feel Bismarck is more than ready to grow its arts community,\" he said. \n\nIn turn, that community could help grow the city, attracting more residents. Borlaug said one of the first things people want to know about before moving somewhere is the arts scene: Is there a symphony? An orchestra? Visual arts? \n\n\"It could help get people to move here,\" he said, and the art produced here is helping tell this area's story. \n\n--- \n\nInformation from: Bismarck Tribune, http://www.bismarcktribune.com \n\nAP Member Exchange shared by The Bismarck Tribune.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"JESSICA HOLDMANThe Bismarck Tribune"},"topics":[{"name":"Entertainment: latest","group":"Entertainment"},{"name":"Entertainment: fine arts news","group":"Entertainment"}],"title":"Number of art galleries increases for Bismarck","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Manatee","zipCode":"34205","state":"Florida","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Bradenton","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Bradenton Herald","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169657775","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"626"},"name":"Bradenton Herald","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Arts","Consumer"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.bradenton.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":["http://bit.ly/2joTPY3","http://www.bismarcktribune.com/"],"sequenceId":"695194450892","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T07:01:00Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:15:37Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

Submitted photo \n \nRing Elementary School second graders received an art lesson in positive and negative space. The students cut half of a symmetrical shape out to make a whole shape. Students could see, firsthand the negative space cut out of the paper and the positive space created by the shape such as a snowman. \n  \n\u201cThe lesson introduces young students to the very abstract concept that there is space they can see, and space that is not there, that they can also see by looking for it,\u201d said Ring Elementary School art teacher Rebecca Whitman. \n \nStudents will also be exploring space in other art venues such as landscapes (foreground, middle ground and background), overlapping and three-dimensional art. Each art lesson builds on the prior one \u2013 all connected by the Elements of Art. \n \nStudents will also explore symmetry more during the year with different materials and subject matter including creating and painting symmetrical butterflies for Mother\u2019s Day.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Entertainment: fine arts news","group":"Entertainment"},{"name":"Education news","group":"Society"}],"title":"Ring Students Learn About Spaces In Art","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Chautauqua","zipCode":"14702","state":"New York","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Jamestown","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Jamestown Post-Journal","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"173538063","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"350"},"name":"Jamestown Post-Journal","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Standard","News"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.post-journal.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695194454320","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:15:39Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

He alleged that the Liberals wanted to wrest police from Mr Grant, a senior Nationals MP.\n\n\"The Nationals wanted police, the right wing faction of the Liberals wanted police,\" he said. \"So she split it in two.\"\n\n\"It's the police who keep us safe from terrorism,\" Mr Foley said.\n\n\"The police commissioner now has to report to two people. It's scandalous and another deal that is counter to the public interest.\"\n\nMeanwhile, the troubled relationship between the NSW attorney-general and minister for police has been addressed, with Ms Berejiklian confirming a reshaping of the much maligned \"justice cluster\".\n\nThe arrangement, whereby as justice and police minister Mr Grant held a more senior position than then attorney-general Gabrielle Upton, was heavily criticised by the legal profession.\n\nThe NSW Bar Association said it provided Mr Grant \"with unprecedented power in determining legal policy without the historical checks and balances\".\n\nThe NSW Law Society warned the arrangement meant police were \"ostensibly responsible for criminal law policy, while at the same time, the traditional roles of the attorney-general as first law officer of the state, which includes preserving civil liberties, are being eroded\".\n\nMs Berejiklian has confirmed the cluster has been reworked so that new attorney-general Mark Speakman, SC, is the lead minister. I'd like to focus more on that.\" \n \nThe 20-year-old Takanashi won five of the first six events this season but failed to add to that tally in the four rounds held in Japan, and the latest result sees her wait for a landmark 50th win continue. \n \n\"My form has dipped and the jump, which is the base for everything, isn't good. I've had to be conscious of doing things that I didn't need to do before,\" she added. \n \n\"I have to place myself where I want to be at the takeoff and then give a burst of power. I did have a decent jump (on my second), moving in one flow from the takeoff to landing after a proper in-run.\" \n \nIto failed to claim her third straight win but showed consistency with her fifth straight podium finish. \n \n\"I'm satisfied as I jumped better than at the last World Cup meet in Zao,\" Ito said. \"The motivation to get results doesn't change, and I need to move forward mentally regardless of whether I did well or not.\"","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Society news","group":"Society"},{"name":"Japan news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Sports: latest","group":"Sports"},{"name":"Sports: winter sports news","group":"Sports"}],"title":"Ski jumping: Takanashi 2nd, Ito 3rd at World Cup event","source":{"category":"Trade","location":{"region":"Asia","subregion":"Eastern Asia","countryCode":"JP","country":"Japan"},"editorialRank":"1","name":"Mainichi Daily News","feed":{"genre":"Opinion","tags":[],"id":"169618705","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"0"},"name":"Mainichi Daily News","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Standard","Society"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://mainichi.jp","publisher":"Mainichi Newspapers"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695194466808","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:15:39Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

Gail Donus is pictured with, Jasper, one of three family cats. Submitted photo \n \nAnimals have always been part of Gail Donus\u2019 life. Her love and concern for those creatures left homeless and abandoned moved her to create the Gail Donus Fund for the Chautauqua County Humane Society. \n  \nThis endowment fund, established in honor of her parents and administered through the Chautauqua Region Community Foundation, will provide medical care and behavioral rehabilitation for shelter animals, thus ensuring their health and safety forever. \n \nDonus says her love for animals, cats in particular, came from her father. \n \n\u201cBack in his day, I suppose it was deemed \u2018unmanly\u2019 to be fond of kittens,\u201d Donus said, \u201cbut Dad never met one he didn\u2019t like.\u201d \n \nDonus currently has three cats in her home: Jasper; Torbie (part tortoise shell, part tabby); and Tasha. \n \n\u201cMy cats are my family and I care for them as such,\u201d she said. \u201cI want all animals to receive the same kind of treatment; I\u2019m very concerned about their care.\u201d \n \nTo learn more about helping the animals in our region, visit crcfonline.org.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[],"title":"A Tail Of Animal Care","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Chautauqua","zipCode":"14702","state":"New York","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Jamestown","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Jamestown Post-Journal","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"173538063","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"350"},"name":"Jamestown Post-Journal","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Standard","News"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.post-journal.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695194467599","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:15:39Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T07:15:39Z","duplicateGroupId":"29395774423","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"CHILDREN","domains":["SUB"],"score":"79"},{"name":"MATERNAL & CHILD HEALTH PROGRAMS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"PARENTING","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"INFANTS & TODDLERS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"67"},{"name":"STUDENTS & STUDENT LIFE","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"SPECIAL EDUCATION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"PRESS RELEASES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"DISABLED PERSONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"US WOMEN, INFANTS & CHILDREN PROGRAM","domains":["SUB"],"score":"72"},{"name":"FAMILY","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"TEACHING MATERIALS & MEDIA","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"}],"wordCount":"302","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395774423&p=2kx&v=1&x=Y7zo_3CHhWDuCZvYctXqug","id":"29395774423","content":"Parent Network of WNY has recently released an updated list of acronyms which will assist special education and disability parents and caregivers. \n \nThe Parent Network of WNY is a provider and education resources for families of individuals with special needs and professionals. Acronyms can sometimes be confusing for parents and caregivers, but the acronym list will be helpful for those involved. \n \nThe list is developed using a crossed-system language with the understanding that families aren\u2019t just in communication with the schools, said Tonia Weichmann, the Transition Coordinator for Parent Network of WNY. \n \n\u201cA lot of our families are working with community agencies and going through different eligibility processes, so I think this list is a great resource for them to take with them to their child\u2019s IEP meetings and any other meetings that involves coordination of services,\u201d she said. \u201cReviewing it ahead of time will help in better educating themselves and becoming a better advocate for their child.\u201d \n \nThe list includes acronyms such as WIC, or the Women Infants and Children program; the OTDA, or the NYS Office of Temporary and Disability Assistance; and PCP, or person-centered planning. In addition to the list of acronyms, the organization also offers a support group director, a military and veteran family resource guide; a recreation director; WNY Family Support Directory; and other information. \n \nThe network serves about 10,000 people a year, and almost 12,000 individuals have developmental disabilities and are in need of support. Likewise, about 30,000 students receive special education services. Parent Network of WNY hosts over 300 workshops a year that serves about 5,000 people. \n \nThe network, which is based out of Buffalo, provides 1-on-1 support and education through resources, workshops and support groups to assist families of individual with disabilities to understand their disability and navigate the support service system. Submitted photo \n \nSalon 1 in Jamestown has provided the door prize for the Sassy Baggs & Beyond Blingo event. \n  \nThose looking to enjoy a fun night out while supporting people with disabilities should plan to attend the Sassy Baggs & Beyond \u201cBlingo\u201d fundraiser Thursday, Feb. 2. \n \nThe event will be held at The Resource Center\u2019s administrative offices at 200 Dunham Avenue in Celoron. Doors will open at 6 p.m., with the Blingo games starting at 7 p.m. Those planning to attend should park in the rear lot and use the far left entrance at the back of the building. \n \nThe evening will feature 10 games of bingo, with handbags from designers such as Betsy Johnson, Guess and Nine West as prizes. Included in the cost of admission are the Blingo games and light refreshments. \n \nThe event is being put on by The Filling the Gap, Inc., which works with The Resource Center to improve the lives of people with disabilities in Chautauqua County. Money raised through Sassy Baggs & Beyond Blingo will benefit the Look Good Fund. The fund was established by former area resident and Resource Center board member Margaret Look, who wanted people with disabilities to be able to obtain money for things such as a haircut or new work clothes.\u201d \n \n\u201cAll proceeds from this event will directly benefit the Look Good Fund, which is put in place to assist ladies and gentlemen with a disability to have the ability to afford the luxury of a professional salon service and professional attire to go on job interviews, all in line with the importance of personal appearance and community integration,\u201d Bardo said. \n \nFor more information, phone Bardo at 661-1477.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[],"title":"\u2018Blingo\u2019 Fundraiser Scheduled For February","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Chautauqua","zipCode":"14702","state":"New York","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Jamestown","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Jamestown Post-Journal","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"173538063","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"350"},"name":"Jamestown Post-Journal","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Standard","News"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.post-journal.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695194468602","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:15:40Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T07:15:40Z","duplicateGroupId":"29395774548","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"EDUCATIONAL INSTITUTION GRADUATION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"79"},{"name":"CLASS RANKING","domains":["SUB"],"score":"79"},{"name":"STUDENTS & STUDENT LIFE","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"FAMILY","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"NURSES & NURSING","domains":["IND"],"score":"78"}],"wordCount":"607","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395774548&p=2kx&v=1&x=4HR3Kwe3SRZTsyb2OFex9w","id":"29395774548","content":"The graduating class of the Erie 2 Chautauqua Cattaraugus BOCES School of Practical Nursing at the Cassadaga Job Corps Academy. Submitted photos \n\nThe Erie 2 Chautauqua Cattaraugus BOCES School of Practical Nursing at the Cassadaga Job Corps Academy marked the graduation of its most recent class this week. \n \nRecently, 15 students completed the intense, one year long training course to prepare for a career as a Practical Nurse. Those in this class were; Susana Arambula, Bianca Benjamin, Erin Betts of Dunkirk, Jacqueline Cruz, Charles DeCoteau, Claire Faustin, Jasmine Graham, Kathryn Hanlon of Dunkirk, Joshua Hutcheson, Fabiola Jordan-Ramos, Tyler-Nyree McDonald Fisher, Christine Nickerson of Dunkirk, Clifford Nickerson of Dunkirk, Erica Paulsen, and Tamara St. Fort. \n \nThe commencement opened with remarks from Job Corps CDP Director Robert Benjamin, and a welcoming address by Laura Bailey from BOCES. Ms. Bailey thanked Job Corps for the ongoing partnership, which dates back further than 10 years, for their ongoing support to make the program possible. She also remarked to the graduates, \n \n\u201cI am thankful for your progress, stamina, strength and urgency. You entered the class with little to no knowledge of the medical field and today, 11 months later, you leave to be responsible for another person\u2019s life.\u201d \n \nFollowing Bailey\u2019s comments was a special video presentation prepared for the class by LPN student Taila McNeill, highlighting their time at Cassadaga, and their preparation for graduation day. Joshua Hutcheson provided a heartfelt address to his classmates and those in attendance. He commented to his class, \u201cAfter what we have been through and done here, there is nothing that we can\u2019t do if we put our minds to it.\u201d He went on to thank by name many of his classmates for their friendship and support, without which he acknowledged he would not have made it. He also thanked the BOCES faculty, his Job Corps RA\u2019s and Counselor, and his family for helping to carry him through the past year. \n \nEach of the graduates were called up by Laura Bailey to receive their pin, award, and diploma. The white, traditional nursing uniform clad graduates each posed on the stage for their family and friends as they moved across the stage back to their seats, where a small gift awaited them. Joshua Hutcheson was presented with the class Valedictorian award. \n \nThe class had co-salutatorians awarded to Christine Nickerson and Jasmine Graham. \n \nThe final step in the Nursing graduation was the reciting of the Nurse\u2019s pledge. Graduates rose and repeated the words that were recited by Ms. Bailey to affirm their commitment to their profession and the care of their future patients. Academy Director Ann Anderson closed the ceremony and reminded the class how important they are in their new role. She thanked the students for the mark they have left on the Center, thanked BOCES for their continued partnership, the families for their support, and wished the graduates luck as they move forward in their new profession. \n \nAnderson went on to remind the class to always be mindful of the team around you, and how important a role everyone plays in caring for the patients they are charged with. \n \nThis successful partnership has helped dozens of men and women secure their career as a Nurse, or launched them into continued education and training to advance their career. BOCES provides the instruction, skill development and clinical experiences, while Job Corps provides the scholarship to eligible students to attend, as well as supportive services throughout the training period. Upon graduation, Job Corps continues follow up and assistance with placement services. \n \nFor more information about the LPN program at the Cassadaga Job Corps Academy, please contact the admissions office by calling 716-595-4200 or visit http://cassadaga.jobcorps.gov.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Education news","group":"Society"}],"title":"Students Complete Practical Nursing Class","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Chautauqua","zipCode":"14702","state":"New York","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Jamestown","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Jamestown Post-Journal","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"173538063","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"350"},"name":"Jamestown Post-Journal","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Standard","News"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.post-journal.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":["http://cassadaga.jobcorps.gov/"],"sequenceId":"695194469426","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:15:40Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}
